All Reviews

  1. This product, though applied properly, transferred to any food my son touched and he tried to quit eating for days because nothing tasted right. However it also didn't stop him from the fingers in the mouth either.
  2. Helped my 4 year old daughter stop chewing her nails. I kept it on her for about a week but after she went back to biting. Applied it for an additional two weeks then stopped. We are not applying it anymore and have been about 3 weeks bite free. Works for my husband as well as long as I can get him to put it on.
  3. I wish I could give this 5 stars. We first tried using this on our 2.5 yr old for thumb sucking and it didn't work. I realize it is not recommended for under 3 as their taste buds are not developed yet. Well, I guess that's right. Our daughter could suck her thumb with no problem and this stuff tastes NASTY!!! I somehow have accidentally tasted it several times and needed gum to get rid of the taste. Now, our lovely 3.5 year still sucks her thumb. We continue to try to use this - but probably could be more consistent. She still manages to suck her thumb (although she doesn't like the taste). We would need to do 2 coats and reapply several times throughout the day for it to hold its yucky power. A lot of maintenance. I'm still giving this product 4 stars as we have tried several other products that really don't work at all. This one does, but at least for us and our incredibly oral child, it still is not a perfect solution to end thumbsucking
  4. MEN: THIS IS NOT FOR YOU!<br />This stuff is extremely shiny--certainly as shiny as women's nail polish. The fact that it's transparent does not take away from the fact that any self-respecting man would be embarrassed to walk around with extremely shiny nails. Very disappointed. I'm returning this ASAP.<br /><br />ALSO: THE TASTE GOES AWAY VERY QUICKLY. I tasted and it tasted moderately sharp and then went away quickly. If you were biting because of nervousness, I think you would easily overcome the bad taste and keep going. I'm so disappointed in the zillion positive reviews. Why did you not point these two things out?

  12. This stuff tastes TERRIBLE. But since that's the point and it has lasted 3 days through 2 showers and probably about 20 hand washings, I'm rating five stars. Haven't bitten my nails since applying it. Took twice to learn that's a bad idea with this stuff?

  14. Great product it really works
  15. I am a mental health counselor in Phoenix, and for as long as I remember having teeth and fingernails, I have put the two together. In the past I have tried a number of different approaches including other polishes - some nasty, some spicy, and some which served just as a reminder as the light reflected off my nails and into my eyes. I have covered my fingernails with band-aids, applied small hairbands around the tips of each finger, employed the rubber-band on the wrist technique, and even underwent psychotherapy for the issue. All to no avail.<br /><br />After having had no fewer than dozens of serious infections, two of which prompted my physician to emphasize the urgency of this matter - and after having removed the white part of my middle finger nail on my dominant hand (while leaving the remainder in tact) on two separate occasions, I thought I would give it one more try.<br /><br />I cannot say that this is going to stop you from biting your nails - because the behavior exists for a reason, and until we either substitute a different behavior or remove the need for the behavior, we're going to continue to pacitfy ourselves by ramming our fingers in between our teeth and gnawing as if we were ravenous dogs. That being said, if you have the desire to quit and the will power to discontinue a behavior when it is brought to your attention, there is a chance that this product will help.<br /><br />This stuff tastes absolutely horrible. It is, quite simply, the most vile flavor I've ever had in my mouth before. I'm a bit of a glutton, though. I painted my nails with Mavala Stop and, after it dried, decided I just HAD to know what it tasted like... so I licked my nail. I sure won't do that again. Others have pointed out that this product rubs off on other things, and I definitely agree with that. The taste found its way onto both my cup of water and my apple cider pancakes. It certainly isn't something I will intentional put anywhere near my face.<br /><br />That brings me to the greatest benefit of this product - self awareness. There's nothing to jolt me from a nice afternoon gnawing at my nails quite as well as the flavor of a bottle of nail polish concentrated on one fingernail. While making those delicious apple-cider pancakes, a little batter got onto my finger. Without thinking, I stuck my finger into my mouth. It. was. horrible.<br /><br />There are only two issues I see with the polish: The first is that it relies upon user compliance with the application regimen. The bottle suggests that it be re-applied every two days. I know, though, that I'm not going to remember to do it every other day, and so I'm going to be doing it daily, just to be safe.<br /><br />The second issue is the shine. As you can see in the photo, this product has a shine comparable to that of other clear nail polishes. It does not have a matte finish and is not a liquid which is simply absorbed into the nail... so this may draw unwanted attention to unsightly nails. Really, though, I'd rather have the attention to pitted, cracked, and short nails, than I would to a swollen, red finger filled with some sort of infectious goop.<br /><br />At the end of the day, if you are consistent in applying Mavala Stop to your finger nails, and you make an honest effort, this product will serve well as a tool to help you get the beautiful nails you deserve!/>That brings me to the greatest benefit of this product - self awareness. There's nothing to jolt me from a nice afternoon gnawing at my nails quite as well as the flavor of a bottle of nail polish concentrated on one fingernail. While making those delicious apple-cider pancakes, a little batter got onto my finger. Without thinking, I stuck my finger into my mouth. It. was. horrible.<br /><br />There are only two issues I see with the polish: The first is that it relies upon user compliance with the application regimen. The bottle suggests that it be re-applied every two days. I know, though, that I'm not going to remember to do it every other day, and so I'm going to be doing it daily, just to be safe.<br /><br />The second issue is the shine. As you can see in the photo, this product has a shine comparable to that of other clear nail polishes. It does not have a matte finish and is not a liquid which is simply absorbed into the nail... so this may draw unwanted attention to unsightly nails. Really, though, I'd rather have the attention to pitted, cracked, and short nails, than I would to a swollen, red finger filled with some sort of infectious goop.<br /><br />At the end of the day, if you are consistent in applying Mavala Stop to your finger nails, and you make an honest effort, this product will serve well as a tool to help you get the beautiful nails you deserve!

After a few applications and several distasteful experiences, she quit biting her nails. The negative reinforcement was exactly what she needed. She used so little of the product that she was able to give it to someone else who had a similar positive experience with it. She hasn't bit her nails in quite a while!
  20. Recieved order quickly but the bottle was broken when I opened it.
  21. My five year old started kindergarten this year! While I'm really enjoying watching her learn new things, I hate some of the behaviors she has picked up from other children! One of those said behaviors was sucking on her fingers. Yes all of her fingers not just her thumbs. This started off as a minor annoyance and swiftly turned into a truly obnoxious behavior. She would literally have her hands shoved in her mouth constantly she would even try to talk while sucking on her hand. Then two of her milk teeth became loose and fell out in which I realized that this habitual hand sucking habit could potentially alter the locations of her emerging adult teeth. So I began searching for a solution.<br />I ordered this Mavala stop as a last resort thinking it would be cruel and now I wish I would have ordered it months prior. I explained to her what I was applying to her fingers and why I was doing it. After a brief discussion I put this on her nails (two coats) and seriously she stopped putting her hands in her mouth within an hour of application. I reapplied it every night for 3-4 days and she has not put her hand nor a finger in her mouth for the past month. I highly recommend this product if you have a little hand or thumb sucker in your life!

  52. My daughter has been sucking her index finger since she was in-utero. I had a 3-D ultrasound done when she was 4 months along, and it showed her sucking her finger. Because it was so important to her, we just let her go and didn't force her to stop...until just a few weeks ago, before she turned 4. We figured it was time to intervene. Her teeth were already malshaped, and we just could not let it go any longer. So, my husband ordered this product after much research. Just like what other reviewers said, it worked OVERNIGHT! After getting a good taste of this stuff, my daughter pretty much stopped sucking her finger. It took her about a week of tossing and turning at night. It broke my heart to see her having withdrawls, but we knew she was just going through this weening process. She is now completely freed of finger sucking. This is the best product and it truly works. Just start out with a tiny bit on the nail. Don't use too much. In hindsight, I wished I stopped this habit when she was around two and a half. Her dentist said it was okay to let it go until age 4, but now that I've gone through this, I would encourage fellow parents to stop their children with finger sucking MUCH sooner. It really alters your teeth and face. It also misshapes your finger. I regret that I let her go too long. We thought it was helping her to sooth herself, and it did, but after a certain point, it just becomes a nasty habit. Just teach them how to comfort themselves in other ways.
  53. I've been biting my nails so long that I can't remember ever using clippers. I wanted to break the habit because my nails look so bad. They're jagged, and the cuticles are ripped. If you're in a similar situation, definitely try this product.<br /><br />It works exactly like a clear nail polish. Apply it to your whole nail if you want, or just the edges that you chew. It will appear shiny for almost 12 hours while it dries. For a man, I recommend applying it at night so you're not shiny the next day.<br /><br />It tastes terrible, like I imagine garden chemicals would taste, and it doesn't wash off easily. If you subconsciously try to bite your nails, you'll get a quick, disgusting reminder to stop. The taste lasts about 60 seconds in your mouth. It's very effective.<br /><br />The only downside is that, if you've really got the habit, you might try to bite your nails in front of other people and make a ridiculous face when you hit the polish instead. Remember, it's not polite to spit, but you'll want to.

  60. After receiving rave reviews from friends that swear by this product and the positive feedback on Amazon I decided to give it a try. I put it on after school the other day and they both didn't suck their thumbs when getting close to bedtime, so I had faith this was going to work. I put them to bed and 1 hour later my son vomitted in bed. He was still asleep and mumbling about the bad taste in his mouth. I immediately took off the product with nail polish remover and he was fine for the rest of the night. He complained the next morning it took all night to get that \\"yucky\\" taste out of his mouth. I checked on my daughter and she was sucking her thumb but not getting sick. I asked her the next morning if her thumb tasted bad and she said \\" a little\\". I put Mavala on again that morning since she sucks her thumb all day and again after a few licks the taste was gone for her. This was my experience, maybe you will have better luck with this product but keep in mind if your child has a weak stomach Mavala is probably not for you. If your child has a strong will to keep sucking, this product will probably not work either.
  61. I used this to help my 4 year old son stop sucking his thumb. I used it along with positive enforcement of the Berenstein bears book and letting him draw pictures on his fingernails with a nail art pen. The first night was no fun, we had to brush his teeth every time he tasted it but, after that he took about a week to gave it up. I would receommend this to anyone!

I have not a clue why it did not affect my daughter. The Mavala does stay on the thumb nail for about 2 to 3 days, which impressed me. My advice to parents with thumb suckers is to use the free methods before jumping into buying something.   102. To the best of my knowledge I've been biting my nails my entire life. I never really thought about it much until I became an adult, and since that point I've always wanted to stop. I just didn't have the willpower. It's hard to break a habit when the source is permanently attached to you. I've had a few periods where I've stopped for a week or two, but eventually just start up again.<br /><br />Then somewhere I read about products like these, and picked this one off of Amazon based on all the positive reviews. I've only applied it twice, which surprisingly enough works out to almost a week and a half of time, and I haven't bitten my nails once. 36 years worth of nail biting and I stopped immediately.<br /><br />This stuff tastes really bad. It's not a particular taste that I can liken to anything else I've ever had in my mouth. It's chemical, foreign, and entirely unpleasant. What's more, it lingers like you wouldn't believe. I've eaten my share of gross things over the years, and generally a quick rinse and a few spits and you're fine. I absentmindedly put one of my fingers in my mouth about three hours ago, I've since eaten dinner and showered, and I swear I can still taste it on my lips. Once you experience this product in your mouth I doubt that your desire to chew your nails will overcome the thought of another dose of this touching your lips.<br /><br />It's also amazingly resilient. Don't worry about having to coat your fingers numerous times a day. I put it on about three days ago and it's still going strong. I can do an entire hand with one dip of the brush, and as such, this 0.3 oz. is probably enough for a couple dozen people.<br /><br />The downside is everything I just mentioned. It's awful, it lingers and you don't want it anywhere near your mouth. You'll forget and try to pick out a stubborn piece of meat that got jammed between your teeth and will cringe when you taste the stuff on your nails. Just wiping your mouth can be dangerous. Forget about eating anything messy with your hands.<br /><br />So does it work? Absolutely. All you need is thirty seconds of willpower to get the stuff on and you're good for at least two or three days. I have no doubts I can keep up with not biting while I use this. The real test will be if I can condition myself to keep my fingers out of my mouth so I can quit using it somewhere down the road..   104. Our 3 1/2yo son had been biting his fingernails for about a year before I looked for a product to help him stop. We tried Mavala Stop and within a week he was 95% cured of the habit! I was a bit skeptical of the small size of the bottle compared to the price, but the bottle lasts months- we only had to buy one. We painted a small amount on the tips of his fingernails every day and that did the trick. We also tasted it- it is really not that bad, not pleasant, but not anything too terrible. We certainly had no point where we felt we needed to wash it off because it was too terrible. You do have to be careful and remind the child not to put their fingers in their mouths while it is on their fingers- I encouraged only fork and spoon use for the week we were using it the most. I tried to think of foods that he could use silverware with instead of finger foods. We explained to him what it was for, and tried to make it positive- \\"soon you won't be biting anymore, that is so exciting!...\\" He liked that and was actually excited about using it. He would actually tell us and ask us to paint his fingernails, we would congratulate him for telling us he had the urge to bite, paint the nails for just one day, and then he would stop. It has now been 3 months since we bought the Mavala Stop, and he has not been biting for the past 2+ months. I would highly recommend this product!

We started talking about how thumbs start to taste bad when you get too big to suck, and that it's a sign your body gives you that you should stop sucking, a rite of passage of growing older like baby teeth falling out. We did this for about two weeks, and then started applying a TINY bit on his thumb after he fell asleep-- I thought doing it this way would make it less of a control issue between us and also thought the bedtime suck would be the hardest to fade so didn't want to start there. He woke up once the first night crying, and I went in and explained that he must be getting to be a bigger boy and congratulations! After this first night, he never woke crying again. We did this for three days and by day two he had stopped sucking altogether. We then did every other day for about two weeks and have stopped completely for ten days now. I think for our son he just needed to break the habit for 1-2 days, he has never looked back and is so proud of himself! We make a big deal each morning of using a pumice stone to get rid of the callus on his thumb. My only regret is not doing it a year earlier!

  154. My two-year old sucked her thumb consistently while sleeping and it was causing her teeth to move. In fact, her bite was affected dramatically. I tried some of the other \\"thumb sucking\\" products on the market that you can purchase at the drugstore and they all failed. She didn't seem to be affected in the least. I also tried the old methods of lemon juice, etc....yeah, right! When I first tried Mavala Stop on her (I painted the entire thumb nail), I realized that when she would pick up her food with her fingers (as toddler's usually eat---picking up a green bean, whatever..) she would get the bad taste in her mouth and stop eating. To alleviate this problem, I began to paint only a small part of her nail, right over the cuticle and onto the finger itself. A tiny tiny bit! This worked because when she would use her fingers to eat, she would not put that much of her thumb in her mouth to taste the cuticle area. However, when thumb sucking, that part of the thumb does enter the mouth. The only thing is that with lots of hand-washing, you may need to apply it more often (maybe each night) because it washes off more easily. Also, if you have painted the entire nail and you wish to remove it, acetone will remove Mavala Stop--you just might have to work at it with several cotton balls and then wash hands VERY WELL to remove the acetone taste. My daughter stopped sucking her thumb immediately. I kept up the Mavala for about a month just to prevent her from picking up the habit again. A last note, her teeth moved back into correct position in about 6 weeks and her bite is perfect. I highly recommend this product.

  172. This is the best stuff that you can get to paint on your child's fingernails to deter thumb-sucking or nail biting. It's much better than [[ASIN:B000T0SZXA Thum Liquid Stops thumb sucking and nail biting - 0.2 Oz / Pack, 3 Packs]], which wore off quickly and had to be constantly reapplied. By contrast, Mavala maintains a nasty taste through the course of the day. Reapplying first thing in the morning, and possibly right before bed, should be plenty.<br /><br />However, success depends on the child. We used this product simultaneously on 3 children: an 8.5 year old that puts his thumb in his mouth (not actually sucking) when he reads, a 6.5 year old who bit her nails until the white was all gone with occasional bleeding, and a 2.5 year old who sucks both thumbs when sleepy/bored. We only had success with one child, the 6.5 year old nail biter. A few days and the habit was broken, and her nails are nice and long. The other two children didn't like the nasty taste and had a sharp decrease temporarily in how often their thumbs were in their mouths, but then they habituated and were right back where they started. When I pointed out her thumb-sucking, my 2.5 year old would say it had worn off, but I'd taste her thumb and it was still nasty.<br /><br />So, if you want to try a paint-on solution, this is what I'd recommend. But, it may very well not work for your child. It only worked for one of our three. I guess we'd have to try a thumb guard or some type of restraint with the other two if we wanted to break the habits.

  183. I've bitten my nails horribly for almost 30 years, and tried all sorts of habit-breaking tactics to try and quit. At the point of giving up I thought I would give this a try. I'm so glad I did. It's been almost 3 weeks now since I first started putting this on, and I haven't bitten my nails once.<br /><br />I noticed a few things about this that surprised me. One, it lasts and lasts, and also soaks into the skin around your fingertip so that if you bite or pull at your cuticles, this will effect that as well. One coat (I brush it over the end of the nail and on the skin around the nail as well) lasts almost 4-5 days. The taste is really bitter and unpleasant, but the worst part is that you can't get it out of your mouth once you've touched your finger to your lips. The other thing I noticed is that it is so powerful, that if you're even eating chips or other finger food, the taste will rub off on what you're eating - even if you're very careful! I've also learned to be careful about touching my lips with any part of my fingertips as it rubs off then too.<br /><br />This has been so effective that I have been using it less and less, and still managing to be deterred from the thought of bringing my hands to my mouth.<br /><br />My sister is now using this with her daughter for thumbsucking as it worked so well for me!

Ever since that one night we weren't awakened anymore and I would say that after one week of using it he doesn't want to, or try to, suck his thumb at all. Last night we didn't put the product on his thumb and checked on him often. No thumb in his mouth that we saw. We would even let him put the product on his thumb to encourage active participation in this endeavor - he was very proud to use it and I think is happy that he's not doing this anymore.<br /><br />My recommendation would be to use this in the summer while school is out based on the length of time it may take your child to stop sucking their thumb.   217. Our daughter is 2 and-a-half and loved to suck her thumb. All of the time, especially when going to sleep. We looked at thumb guards, but they looked so bulky for a toddler, so we bought this product after a recommendation from a friend. For about a week, we tried to get our daughter to stop sucking her thumb by encouragement and rewards, but she was too young for that to work and said that stopping sucking her thumb would make her feel \\"sad.\\" You know, she would say \\"go away,\\" and then she would suck her thumb. So, we bought Mavala and explained to her that this would help her stop sucking her thumb. At first, she didn't want it, but then she said she wanted to stop sucking her thumb and wanted to try it. We put one coat on her left thumb, and immediately were told, \\"I don't like that,\\" and \\"wash that off\\" and \\"I don't like that taste.\\" Heard it many times and each time, we tried to change the subject. And, guess what -- she STOPPED sucking her thumb. At night, this girl who always fell asleep with her thumb in her mouth stopped as well. It wasn't the easiest night, but the next day and night things were so much better. We are on day 3 and we reapplied a coat to make sure we don't lose any of the gains, but so far, this is working like a charm and, as a parent, have to say it has been relatively painless. Sure, it was cute when her thumb was in her mouth and she was sleeping. But it wouldn't be cute when in a few years her teeth would be all misaligned and we would be paying substantial orthodontic bills. In short, if you are considering this product even for someone as young as two and a half, as long as he or she can somewhat understand what is going on, then this product could not be more recommended.

  220. I bit my nails for nearly 20 years. Finally, about a year ago, I bought this product, and I was finally able to stop. I had tried everything I could think of - just focusing on not biting, rubber bands on my wrist, and other random stuff that really just did not work. This stuff is great.<br /><br />You paint it on your nails. It looks like clear polish. It coats on pretty thin. I'm female, but I think as a man it's subtle enough wearing it wouldn't be too bad. It adds some shine, so it's not invisible. Anyway, you will notice anytime you put your hands on or in your mouth. I thought I just had my hands near my mouth when biting my nails, but I realized I put them near my mouth other times as well, such as when eating foods with my fingers. You'll find you want to use silverware or eat a lot more carefully - no more licking food off your fingers! Anyway, for a chronic nailbiter, you've probably already started before you notice, and you don't want to leave a hangnail after that. At least that was the way for me. With this stuff, you'll stop immediately.<br /><br />The taste is definitely unpleasant, but it definitely won't make you sick. The best part was, despite nearly 20 years of biting, after using this stuff for 2 or 3 weeks, I stopped using it, and I didn't start biting again. The habit had just disappeared.<br /><br />To not relapse, I recommend keeping your nails fairly short. Having long nails is annoying if you're not used to it. Also, at the first sign of relapse, use the polish again.

He was a little sad for the first few hours, but quickly got over it and I'm so happy I tried this. He has really opened up without that thumb in his mouth all the time! He chats constantly and seems to enjoy his newfound thumb-freedom! I have not had to reapply it, which amazes me because he ALWAYS had that thumb in his mouth and I thought I'd never get him to quit, let alone so easily. Wish I had found this product sooner, but I would recommend it to anyone with a similar problem. Best ten dollars spent ever!

Many people who found this product ineffective had children under 3, although some were lucky enough that it worked despite the younger age of their children. It took Kool-aid and flavored applesauce to get the taste out of her mouth.<br /><br />So, as a parent I love this product, no more nail biting! But as a finger food eater, I hated it (I had to try after the Cheetos incident).<br /><br />So if everything else has failed, try this. It's expensive, but I doubt you'd use the whole bottle, or you have a more stubborn child than I do.

By day two he was done and I never had to reapply. Tasted the stuff myself... Horrible and nasty, but effective. Some reviewers stated that you shouldn't use this if your kid eats with his/her fingers because they might get their finger in their mouth and you will have a hard time getting them to eat it again. I agree to a degree, but my child was easy to reason with and I told him to use a fork and the issue was gone. So maybe you just have to consider why you need this product and whether or not your kid will listen.

  301. We have an ultrasound of our daughter sucking her thumb. We knew stopping this habit was going to be hard. Boy was I wrong. In 3 days, no more thumb sucking. The first night was rough since she put her thumb in her mouth dead asleep and it woke her up. On the 3rd night she did put her thumb in her mouth but we didn't know until morning. We left Kool-Aid on her nightstand. She took a drink and went back to sleep. We still apply it occasionally but she really doesn't need it. I think it helps her remember to not put her thumb in her mouth. She has gone 2 months with very few slip ups. We are so proud of her because she did this as much as the product. We also think she was ready.<br /><br />How we used it. From reviews we read we don't put much on. We only put it at the base of her thumb (by the cuticle). We never went farther up than 1/2 way up her thumb. This is important since the taste will last on the her thumb for a couple of days and every time she would eat a snack she could taste it. When she swims we do put it on every night. But other than the first week we realized we didn't need it everyday. Also for the first week we had a cup of kool-aid for her to drink if she did taste it. We weren't trying to punish her for sucking her thumb just make her aware of sucking her thumb. This was the first remedy tried.<br /><br />Now for the interesting part. I am sure the manufacturer wouldn't indorse this. My sister has a 7 year old son that can stick his tongue half way up his nose. What turned into a cool trick is now a gross problem. He isn't aware of even doing it. He was actually disrupting his class when he was at school. He was unaware he was using his tongue & if an another kid saw it they would laugh. My sister had tried everything. When she heard I bought this she decided to try it. She washed under his nose & then put lotion under his nose. She then applied a dab (doesn't even brush it on). It did the trick. If he starts it up, she just puts a dab. It works. Mavala has made him aware when he is sticking his tongue upward. I asked my nephew if it burned and said it only did once because my sister didn't put the lotion first. But otherwise no. He said it works too.<br /><br />I am sure the last part was more than people wanted to know but the product really works.Mavala has made him aware when he is sticking his tongue upward. I will let you know once I slip up.<br /><br />EDIT: Tastes strong and terrible. The stuff works. I haven't bitten my nails in over a week, and they have grown longer than they've ever been (which isn't all that far, haha). For fellow guys, you will want acetone to remove layers before applying new ones. I just kept reapplying it every other day, and it started to build up a texture on my nail. I'm not very good at appyling it to begin with.<br /><br />I'm moving my rating up to 5/5 from 4/5.
  442. Purchased this for my almost four year old son, who has been a thumbsucker since he was 6 months old. He was ready to stop sucking his thumb, but admitted he couldn't do it on his own. After reading the reviews for Mavala Stop we thought this would be the best and most cost effective attempt at \\"quitting.\\"<br /><br />We applied the Mavala on his thumbs, and the smell was less than appetizing. We were all confident (my son included) this was going to do the trick. I will mention that he only sucks his thumb at night and during naps. Well he subconsciously put his thumb in his mouth while sleeping. Apparently the taste was so bad, he started gagging and ultimately vomited. He was hysterical, partially because this all occurred while he was half asleep. It took 15 minutes to get the taste out of his mouth after brushing his teeth/tongue twice, giving him three child size cups of water, and finally giving him a piece of chocolate. He didn't suck his thumb for about 3 days after this incident, for fear the Mavala flavor would still be there, but once he realized it was gone the thumb sucking came back full force. If his thumsucking habits were different (not during sleep), I would absolutely use this. However, I can't expect him to not suck his thumb when he is sound asleep and the thumb is a constant topic of conversation, therefore constantly on his mind.

At first he kept sucking his finger then while sucking he was making a strange cringe with his eyebrows. After the cringe removed his finger and tried another. Same thing, but not the third it must of hit him a little harder cause he took out his tounge for like 5 minutes drooling while watching tv. Not once did he stop watching tv. My wife and I were laughing so hard and that his older brother came to see him and he started laughing too. Thats when noticed something is up and he came running to me with his tongue out trying to talk. Made me laugh harder. So I gave him water and he stopped with the tongue out thing. 10 minutes later he put his finger in his mouth again and he vomited everywhere. Another 30 mins later he sucked his finger again and threw up again. Then he ate some finger food and 5 minutes into eating threw up again.<br /><br />That was that last day he sucked his fingers for about 2 months. Started again, but then again we only did it once. We cured him after 2 weeks by adding it the back 1/2 part of his nail. That way he can eat finger food without it mixing up.<br /><br />Great product. Also good for practical joke.   447. My pediatric dentist recommended this product for my six and a half year old daughter who is beginning to get her adult teeth and is experiencing movement of her teeth due to the thumb sucking. She has been completely addicted to her thumb since she was eight weeks old. Other motivators did not work because it was a subconscious act for her. Thanks to the other reviews we knew to put it just on the top of her nail and thumb, so it would not affect the taste of her food. We started on a holiday weekend, in case it was a difficult transition, so that she wouldn't be alone at school. It started working immediately. She knew it was a bad taste she didn't want in her mouth. She accidentally sucked it a few times, especially at night and the taste was traumatic for her, she had to drink a lot of milk to get rid of the taste. She was so used to sucking her thumb to go to sleep we had to give her lots of extra TLC to help her go to sleep the first night. After that, it was easy. It's only 7 days in, but I definitely would recommend this product as my daughter won't suck her thumb when the Mavala is on and now she sleeps differently to accommodate for not having her thumb to suck on and she sits differently when she watches TV (another time she sucked her thumb a lot). It's changing her habits and I have no doubt after the 33 recommended days, she will have kicked the habit. If she starts sucking it again, I will start using it again. I was amazed by the fast results!!
  448. I am a 27 year old female who has been biting my nails since 2nd grade and I love this product. I've been able to quit on and off throughout my life but for the most part I'm extremely addicted to nail biting. This product does not smell or look funny, so it's very easy to just put on top of nail polish or on bare nails. I carry it in my purse so that I can reapply it every other day and never have an excuse for accidentally biting them. You have to apply GENEROUSLY. It's not like putting on nailpolish where you put on a normal amount of liquid and spread nicely. You have to really slosh it on or else it might not be strong enough. I highly recommend this product to help stop nail biting. I've been using it about 2 weeks and I haven't been \\"cured,\\" but I think that in time I will basically 'forget' to bite my nails after not doing it for so long. The taste is sooo gross and it stays in your mouth for an extra minute, so you really get punished and learn your lesson! I keep my fingers out of my mouth now!
  449. The taste is a good deterrent from nail biting. My primary complaint though is if you have to wash your hands a lot, which in working in the healthcare field I do, plan to use two coats and apply at least every other day, if not daily. I found if I only use one coat it doesn't take long at all for it to thin and wear off. Usually by the end of the day I can barely see it on my nails, so doing an extra coat helps it last longer.

  504. After I read the reviews I couldn't wait to receive the product. My 8-year-old son needed to stop sucking his thumb. I was desperate so I spent the $12 hoping this would be the answer. I started to see him sucking his thumb less in the first week but by week two it didn't even seem to phase him. Either he got used to the awful taste or he found a way to remove it. I used it myself to help me stop biting my nails, and I haven't bitten them since, but the rest of the family suffered for it. The taste of MALVA Stop gets into food, if you prepare it with your hands. Not only does it ruin the taste of your nails, it ruins the taste of the food you eat with your hands. So if you plan to use this, try not to eat things like fried chicken, tacos or chips. Also it seems to wear off rather easily.

She didn't nap. That night I applied a little more on both thumbs. We were wondering why she wasn't waking in the night, until we found her in the morning sucking on her thumb like it wasn't covered in the most bitter foul tasting nail polish ever. She wants to stop, but as soon as the lights are out a robot takes over her arm and guides that thing straight to her mouth. Her teeth are messed up and she can't pronounce the 'k' sound. He told me that someone put something bad on his thumb and I told him it was medicine so he didn't have to suck his thumb anymore. My son no longer sucks his thumb and it worked right away! Highly recommend this product!
  567. My five year old had a bad habit of sucking his thumb. My husband and I had tried everything we could to get him to stop. You name it, we tried it. In desperation I bought this product. That night we snuck in to his room and applied it to his thumb. In the middle of the night, we could hear him gagging and crying. In the morning, he told us that his thumb tasted like oil. That day, he tried everything to take it of off his thumb. He must of washed his hand 20 times. Nothing worked. It took two week and our son is completely broken of his habit. I would recomend this product to anyone who can't get their child to stop sucking there thumb.
  568. My 5 yr old daughter quit sucking her thumb in just a few days after someone recommended this product to me.   571. We thought we had tried everything to help my five year old to stop sucking his thumb. He was getting really discouraged that he kept failing with everything he tried. It was a really hard habit for him to break. His teeth have gotten really bad and he has been getting horrible canker sores in his mouth. So finally we made an appointment to have an appliance placed in his mouth. The dentist couldn't get us in for four months so I scheduled the appointment but decided to check the internet one last time. We have tried other paint on products but he just sucked them off so I wasn't very hopeful, but this product got good reviews so I ordered it.<br /><br />So far it has worked like a charm. It is really nasty so sucking it off hasn't been a problem. He has also tried washing it off but that doesn't work either. It hasn't been easy for him. Sometimes he is so proud of himself for going five days without sucking and then other times he gets really frustrated. Once when he had had a hard day at school and wanted to suck his thumb to relieve the stress he cried and exclaimed \\"The worst day of my life was the day that stuff came in the mail.\\" It is a bit heartbreaking to watch him struggle, but I think in the long run it is for the best. I don't know how long it will take before he stops wishing he could suck his thumb, but I have to say this is a very effective product. It saved us $275.00 in dental fees. I would definately give this a try if a gentler approach doesn't work.

  601. This product is outstanding! We tried everything possible to help our preschooler stop thumb sucking. Nothing worked. We heard of a product called Thum. It's applied on the finger nail and deters thumb sucking. Do not buy Thum. It is incredibly mild and had no impact on breaking my childs habit. Its made with Cayenne pepper and actually tastes good! Mavala Stop is applied the same way as Thum, however it literally stopped our child's thumb sucking habit on the spot.   602. I bought this product for my 7 and 4 year old children. Both kids are nail biters and despite my best efforts to get them to stop, nothing worked. That is, until I bought this nail polish. After the first application it began its magic and after only a week of applying it (and that's only been two applications because you paint it on once every two days) the nail biting is all but gone. I have to tell you, I tried it myself and the taste is absolutely terrible. It goes in mild but after a second it is repulsive and depending on how long the finger was in your mouth it tends to stay with you. A drink of water and washing the lips gets rid of the taste though, but I have to admit, it is a powerful deterrent--and no amount of hand washing gets rid of it on the fingers! My kids actually came close to vomiting because the taste was so terrible. The only downside comes when eating, especially with my 4 year old because her fingers sometimes go into her mouth by accident. You could count that as a positive though if you are picky about table manners.<br /><br />My kids fingers were in very bad shape before using this polish making them self conscious and ashamed to have others look at them. Now the nails are actually starting to grow and the ragged appearance is starting to go away. They are now proud to show off their shiny nails and that is worth much more to me than any price this polish could possibly be.<br /><br />My advice is to go ahead and get this polish if your own kids need help with nail biting or thumb sucking and are at an age to appreciate the help. I've told mine that the polish is there to help make their nails all better and they love getting their \\"medicine\\" to make their nails shiny. This stuff works and is worth every penny.

  605. It certainly tastes terrible and it certainly discouraged me from biting my nails. However, I wound up tasting it ALL THE TIME -- anytime my fingers came in contact with my mouth, during routine activities like flossing or eating finger foods. The taste is extremely bitter and unpleasant, and quite long-lasting, so if I made the mistake of trying to pick a piece of food from my teeth or something, I'd pay for it for a while. It also seems to be transferable -- that is, if I touch my lip, my lip will keep the offensive taste long afterwards.<br /><br />So yeah, it works, and maybe if purchased for children who need a stronger deterrent, it's the right product. For myself, if I ever needed to buy another bottle (hopefully not) I might look for something that provides a less intense reminder to not bite my nails. The price of the taste is somewhat overkill when all I need to a little slap on the wrist.

I have never written a review on Amazon before, but feel that if you have a child who can't stop sucking his/her thumb: read this!<br /><br />My six year old daughter sucked her thumb very often. She could not be stopped: in the car, watching t.v., at bedtime. Basically, if she wasn't talking or using her hands, her thumb was in her mouth. We tried bribery, we tried a band aid, we tried a glove. Then I brought a product called Thum that I saw at the drugstore. This is also painted onto the fingernail. She could wash it off (and did so at school) and it faded quickly so the spicy cayenne pepper taste would lessen and she could tolerate it.<br /><br />I was ready to order a hypnosis CD to assist with breaking the habit, via Amazon, when I found a link to Mavala. My dentist said once her permanent teeth started coming in she would need to cease the sucking. A few tantrums occurred which we assist her through by distracting her with book reading, a bubble bath and lots of love and encouragement. She insisted that she couldn't have her blanket because it gave her the desire to suck even more.<br /><br />The taste: I touched my tongue to her nail and the taste is truly awful, a sour acidic chemical taste that dulls the tip of the tongue and then the taste shoots down both sides of the tongue. It lingers for quite some time.<br /><br />I took the advice of another reviewer and kept a glass of water by her bedside, When she would unconsciously suck her thumb while sleeping the putrid taste would wake her up and she would drink the water and fall back to sleep.<br /><br />It is day 6 and my daughter is doing fantastic. She doesn't like to talk about it, but her confidence is visible and my husband and I are overjoyed! I know first hand the difficulties thumb sucking can cause, I sucked my thumb until I was 12, so the desire I know, is strong. I went through braces, neck gear and needed to be re-taught how to swallow properly via a speech therapist. Try this product! It's been exhausting so I FINALLY ordered mavala stop and put it on her immediately. It worked from day two...day one, she tried to suck her thumb but gagged a little and wanted to drink some water to get the taste out! From that point on, she hasn't sucked her thumb or cried! I wish I had done this first, it would have saved alot of tears and money. It's well worth it.

  717. I purchased this is a last ditch effort to get my then 13mth old son to stop sucking his two fingers. He had sucked them to the point of being literally raw and blistering. We'd tried just about everything else we could think of before turning to this product.<br /><br />The day it arrived in the mail I immediately pulled it out of the box, pulled my son onto my lap and proceeded to paint those two finger nails. At first it seemed to work. One suck and his faced screwed up like he'd just sucked a lemon. After trying desperately not to laugh, I spent the next two hours blissfully NOT saying \\"Don't suck your fingers!\\" The silence was heaven. But then after about 2hrs I noticed he was happily sucking away again. So I reapplied the product. Another 2 hours without sucking. Another coat...and so on for the next 48hrs (except while sleeping of course).<br /><br />By the end of the second day my son had GROWN ACCUSTOMED TO THE TASTE and would suck his fingers within minutes after applying the product!<br /><br />We ended up wrapping his hand in socks, mittens, and first aid wraps for the next two months (taking it off only for eating) while the fingers healed. When we finally stopped wrapping his hand he seemed to need to suck less than before. Since then he continues to suck lightly whenever he is tired or hungry or nervous. Because it hasn't gotten raw or blistered again, we've let it be. If it does get raw again we may try the Mavala again since we still have the bottle, but I wouldn't buy it again.<br /><br />Incidentally, during one application I had the misfortune to spill some on my jeans and hands. Although I immediately washed my hands *thoroughly*, the taste remained *very* strong for several hours. I accidentally touched my lips by habit once and was rewarded with a lingering AWFUL HORRIBLE taste on my lips for over 2 hours! It took DAYS for the taste to completely go away from my fingers!!! Thus, I can say with some certainty that it ought to stop most grownups from EATING anything at all that requires using your fingers to assemble or eat it (the taste transfers from your fingers to the food), let alone stopping someone from biting their nails! It came off my jeans with one run through the washer.<br /><br />******* April 2011 UPDATE*******<br />I am currently using that same bottle on my *second* son who is now 3 and still sucking his thumb UNLESS I paint this stuff on his thumbs. He HATES the taste and cries whenever we put it on him because he knows it means he can't suck his thumb, but the sucking is already affecting his jaw and teeth alignments, so on it goes. I'm working on remembering to apply it every morning. I think if I can get more consistent it'll do the trick for this guy. Guess my first boy was just more tolerant/stubborn, depending on how you look at it. ;-)ps from EATING anything at all that requires using your fingers to assemble or eat it (the taste transfers from your fingers to the food), let alone stopping someone from biting their nails!   761. [[ASIN:B000PI36W6 Mavala® Stop (0.3 oz)]]<br />My three year old daughter has been suffering from severe trichotillomania (hair pulling), trichophagia (hair eating) and thumb sucking. The habits seem to go hand-in-hand in her case. Her pediatrician was concerned because she was eating the hair as she sucked her thumb which could cause a blockage in her intestines which could be fatal if not discovered and removed surgically. We've been seeing a psychologist and trying everything to stop these habits (such as using other polish that claims to do the same thing as Mavala, we also tried having her wear gloves, we tried distraction, tried putting bandaids on her thumbs, tried stress relievers like squishy toys for her to squeeze and bracelets for her to fiddle with, we tried a reward program where she would get surprises if she didn't suck her thumb or pull her hair, we tried disciplining her when she would do these things, we had her pediatrician and her dentist talk to her about it, we tried everything). It has been a source of constant worry for me because I didn't know what to do and I was so fearful that she would be teased about this one day and that would make it even worse, not to mention the effect on her self esteem and the potential health hazards.<br />We started using Mavala a few weeks ago (after having tried other similar products with no luck). I must say I was hoping for the best, but not expecting much due to the strong attachment my daughter had with her thumb. But after reading many reviews and seeing other people having positive results, I figured we had nothing to lose. Our next step was going to be medicating our daughter based on advice from a psychiatrist and we really didn't want to go down that road.<br />I was worried that my daughter would not let me apply the Mavala to her nails because we had tried similar products and she would try to prevent us from putting them on her because she said they tasted yucky (but obviously not yucky enough to stop her from sucking her thumb). So I explained to her that now that she was three years old, she was big enough to use a \\"special polish\\" on her nails. The special polish was Mavala. I made a big deal about it and she became excited about trying it. I told her it would make her nails shiny. So she sat in my lap and allowed me to put it on her nails without a fuss. That first night was difficult because she kept saying she wanted her \\"thumbkin\\", and she wanted the polish off. She went to bed in tears. That is so hard for a mom to see. But I kept reminding myself why I was doing this. We put the Mavala polish on her nails every night before bed for several weeks. She continued to allow me to put it on her because she felt so special being able to use this polish (it's like she would forget every night that she didn't like the taste of it). For a few nights she would cry herself to sleep because she would try to suck her thumb and then when she would get a taste of it she would be so upset. It probably took about a week before she stopped trying to suck her thumb. We continued to use the Mavala every night for about 6-8 weeks just to be sure the habit was broken. Sometimes I would just put it on her thumbs and not her other fingers since that was really my only concern.<br />I'm extremely happy to report that this product was a miracle for us. It worked. It actually worked. It saved my sanity, but more importantly, it saved my daughter's life. I truly believe that. Her trichotillomania (hair pulling) and trichophagia (hair eating) also stopped when she stopped sucking her thumb. That is life saving. This product works!!!!! I can't even begin to say how much this product means to me and my family. It's absolutely what we needed and I'm so thankful for everyone who posted positive reviews. I was skeptical because even a little bit of a nail polish remover taste hasn't seemed to work and most just wear off after biting your nails once. Since I got my order last night...I've put it on, and ....first attempt to bite I didn't initially taste it, but boy oh boy is the aftertaste rancid. It takes forever to get the after taste out of your mouth and is a HUGE reminder not to bite. I even tried brushing my teeth to get it out and it didn't help much. After ashing my hands several times it still hasn't worn the taste off of it. Whatever the manufacturers did to make this product to terrible tasting and long lasting...it worked. I absolutely hate putting my hands in my mouth with this stuff on. I'm betting I'll have nice long nails before too long.
  781. My 4 year old son constantly bit his nails, and this worked well as long as he had it, but he kept fussing about not being able to eat, and refused application all together. I had to sneak it on his nails when he was asleep. After a while, he outgrew biting his nnails without the product. So, I can say, yes, it did the trick!

The first time we applied it to our 2-year old daughter's thumbs, she stopped. We applied it every night for two-weeks (just for good measure), and it worked great! In fact, when she saw her friends sucking their thumbs, she would tell them to stop. I couldn't be more pleased with this product!
  783. I became extremely confident that this would be the solution for my 4 year old daughter to stop biting her nails and fingers. I applied a coat as soon as I received it. She went to school and after inspection of her nails found she had bit her nails. Apparently the awful taste was not enough to keep her from biting her nails. For instance, you can't really eat chips without tasting the bitterness in your mouth. If you try to take meat out of a cold meat container, you run the risk of contaminating the meat underneath. Eating a sandwich is a problem because the bitterness wears off onto the bread.<br /><br />So far it has been about 3 weeks and I have not bitten my nails. I actually have nails.   859. I wished I knew about it earlier. My son stopped sucking his thumb in two weeks after 3 or 4 applications. Broke a habit which had lasted nearly 5 years in a fortnight.<br />Will recommend this product without hesitation.
  860. This product is amazing. I've been biting my nails for more than 15 years (I'm almost 22), and I managed to stop completely in three weeks.<br /><br />Mainly, I had to become aware of what I was physically doing so I could stop doing it. Because of the horrible, bitter, lingering taste of Mavala Stop, I gradually became aware of what I was doing and could consciously think about my actions. It forced me to be conscious of my bad habit. Secondly, the nasty taste removed any enjoyment or stress relief I got from biting my nails since it was so incredibly unpleasant. I became very wary, very quickly. This combination of factors made it possible for me to stop, which I thought I could never do.<br /><br />The taste is really horrible. It's like acetone (nail polish remover), bitter, rotten wood, and some sort of fish put together. It has a very chemical taste with a sweet undertone that makes for a horrible experience. The taste is also very durable and lingering. If you licked a nail painted with Mavala Stop, it would take a few minutes to get the taste out. The taste was so bad, in my opinion, that getting it off of my teeth, lips, and tongue when I slipped up stopped whatever I was doing or thinking about. It's very, very gross. Two coats of polish will last for more than one full week before rubbing off. It can help to freshen it up during the week to keep the taste at full unpleasantness.<br /><br />It ruined finger foods for me during the time I used it. My fingers periodically touched my lips while I was eating, and the nasty taste would rub off slightly. This made me lick my lips a lot to remove the taste quicker-- it's easier to get it over with quickly than to try to avoid it on your lips--which made them lose moisture and chap badly. So you should also buy some lip balm at the same time. If you touch a nail with a fingertip, it will rub off there, too, and from there can transfer to coffee cups, pencils, hors d'oeuvres, etc. Wash your hands before you eat anything that might touch them.<br /><br />There were no English directions packaged with the product. I don't think this is a problem, since the directions are pretty much obvious (Shake. Paint nails. Gag at taste) but it might be a concern for some people. A great deal of other languages were represented in the instruction pamphlet, including German, Portugese, Spanish, French, and a number of Asian languages.<br /><br />Mavala Stop has a shine comparable to clear nail polish, but not as shiny as premium or ultra-shine clear nail polish. Your nails will probably not look natural, but if that's a concern, you could probably lie and say it's just a nice, buffed manicure. It could easily be worn over nail polish and would probably work like an extra protective topcoat. The shiny quality rubs out over time. At the end of a week it will be duller and more matte, but also less effective.<br /><br />The bottle holds roughly the same amount as a regular bottle of nail polish, but Mavala Stop seems to be of a slightly thinner consistency. I recommend carrying the bottle with you in a pocket or purse so that if you must do something to your nails, it can at least be a touch-up. Washing your hands seems to dull it out more quickly, and removes some of the taste, but not all, by far. It does not wash out with water and soap, but the power is reduced.<br /><br />The only reason you would fail with this product is if you can't bring yourself to enforce it. You have to make sure you put it on and touch it up. The temptation of not putting it on or letting it wear off quickly is certainly there. I would advise getting someone else involved who will scold you or remind you about it.<br /><br />I would recommend this product to anyone. The price is worth it as it works very well. I am very pleased with the result.thing that might touch them.<br /><br />There were no English directions packaged with the product. I don't think this is a problem, since the directions are pretty much obvious (Shake. Paint nails. Gag at taste) but it might be a concern for some people. A great deal of other languages were represented in the instruction pamphlet, including German, Portugese, Spanish, French, and a number of Asian languages.<br /><br />Mavala Stop has a shine comparable to clear nail polish, but not as shiny as premium or ultra-shine clear nail polish. Your nails will probably not look natural, but if that's a concern, you could probably lie and say it's just a nice, buffed manicure. It could easily be worn over nail polish and would probably work like an extra protective topcoat. The shiny quality rubs out over time. At the end of a week it will be duller and more matte, but also less effective.<br /><br />The bottle holds roughly the same amount as a regular bottle of nail polish, but Mavala Stop seems to be of a slightly thinner consistency. I recommend carrying the bottle with you in a pocket or purse so that if you must do something to your nails, it can at least be a touch-up. Washing your hands seems to dull it out more quickly, and removes some of the taste, but not all, by far. It does not wash out with water and soap, but the power is reduced.<br /><br />The only reason you would fail with this product is if you can't bring yourself to enforce it. You have to make sure you put it on and touch it up. The temptation of not putting it on or letting it wear off quickly is certainly there. I would advise getting someone else involved who will scold you or remind you about it.<br /><br />I would recommend this product to anyone. The price is worth it as it works very well. I am very pleased with the result.
  861. I've been biting my nails forever, I have tried everything. This product works better than anything.   864. The amazon reviews for these types of products are really frustrating. Most 5 star reviews are clearly fake testimonials.<br /><br />I'm trying to help my 6 yr old stop biting her nails and I've tried each product on myself.<br /><br />\\"Thumb\\" is totally useless and doesn't taste like anything. Active ingredient listed as Cayenne pepper extract.<br /><br />\\"Malvala Stop\\" is bitter but I don't really find the taste all that offensive. It might be useful for a very taste sensitive child or an adult that just want's a reminder. My 6 yr old says she doesn't like the taste but it's not enough to get her to stop. The taste is slow to develop. Active ingredient Denatonium Benzoate.<br /><br />\\"Hoof stop the bite\\" is very bitter and the taste comes on much quicker than Malvala. Bitterness lingers for a long time. Active ingredient Denatonium Benzoate (branded Bitrex).<br /><br />Hoof wins in that it tastes the worst and must have a higher concentration of Denatonium Benzoate. My main concern with both Hoof and Malvala is that the lingering bitterness will desensitize my daughter too it. Since the bad taste doesn't go away she may just keep biting once she starts. We'll see.
  865. Great product. I bite my nails all the time, like down to raw sometimes. Started young, never was able to shake it, and its really bad when I am stressed out, which is often these days. With this stuff on my nails, I wont go near em - i tried about 3 times, and learned quickly. Haven't in nearly a week, and they are already healing and growing back. This stuff tastes REALLY BAD and wont come off regardless of washing, so its bang for buck. Gonna stick with this product for a month or so and hopefully that will de-program my brain and will be no longer a nail-biter. Only word of caution for this product - its really strong, and you will taste it if you are not careful while eating with your hands. Also, i accidentally gave my 1 year old a piece of apple and she got a dose, accompanied by some crying. Overall these challenges are avoidable if careful, and its a really effective product. 5 stars.

  875. This worked to stop my son from putting his thumb in his mouth, but I think it is worth sharing our experience with it. My son was still sucking his thumb at age 4 when he entered pre-kindergarten - he sucked it ALL THE TIME. We wouldn't have really been concerned had he only sucked his thumb at home, but he was doing it at school and as a consequence was getting sick quite often. The first time we tried this it immediately prevented him from putting his thumb in his mouth (it really does taste terrible, I tried some on my fingernail) - what we hadn't anticipated was that his thumb sucking was also a comfort/coping mechanism at school and the immediate elimination of it resulted in him acting out in uncharacteristic ways - queue Bruce Banner's change into the Incredible Hulk. Once we figured this out, we decided that the middle of the school year was not the time to eliminate his thumb sucking. Trying to get this stuff off is quite a chore. I tried fingernail polish remover, but that didn't work so I ended up filing it off with a nail file. Flash forward to the summer and we tried it again. In addition to having this painted on his thumbnails, I had a reward system for every week that he didn't suck his thumb, ending in the eventual earning of a big-boy two wheeler bike when he was thumb-sucking free for two months. This worked great and he hasn't sucked his thumb since. Bottom line, this stuff kept my son from putting his thumbs in his mouth, but he needed to be ready to give up the habit so the absence of the thumb sucking didn't have negative consequences.

  910. I've had a nail biting issue since I was 4 years old- I turn 32 here in less than a month so for almost 30 years I've been contending with this. I've tried all kinds of cures under the sun to stop my habit but this problem was deeper than something of a simple 'habit'.<br /><br />For anyone reading this review and thinking of this product to stop a serious, chronic habit- I want to recommend a few things.<br /><br />If you struggle with anxiety as many nail-biters do, consider visiting your doctor, a therapist, even a psychologist. Nail-biting is a symptom, not the problem. Part of the reason I'm finally able to tackle this is that I'm not only using this product to deter me but I have now been on an anti-anxiety medication for a few months prior. This has made me far more capable in terms of trying to take these OCD habits by the horns and work them out. You need management skills, to understand antecedents to your behaviors, and how to modify those situations. So ending your nail-biting habit if anxiety related might take more than a simple paint on product.<br /><br />Secondly, it states to use it once every other day. I use it almost every day - and become rather aware when the taste is fading and make note to keep coating it on. It's working great, my nails are the longest they've EVER been, and I'm thoroughly happy even if the taste of this stuff is completely rancid. (Aka- it does the job it's supposed to).<br /><br />Keep the bottle somewhere visible and where you frequently have your line of vision (but obviously away from children). For me, I set it next to my monitor screen. I'm on my computer daily - so I'm bound to notice it being right there. Don't let it go out of sight, out of mind.<br /><br />KEEP your nail clippers handy! Even if it seems easier just to bite or peel away an uneven bit of nail, you'll spare most of it by just clipping off those rough edges. Sounds like common sense, I know. But anyone with an OCD habit for nail-biting understands what this refers to and how much of a 'trigger' those rough nail edges are. Keep all these things available,<br /><br />Next, I also take Biotin. It's a supplement- you can get it from any kind of drug store or Wal-Mart, etc. Read the bottles carefully, make sure you grab the one-a-day variety. You don't want to have to pop 3 of these a day to get your recommended dosage. Biotin helps improve nail strength- and many chronic nail biters I know have flimsy nails. Mine are definitely stronger - and my hair! So double benefit.<br /><br />Mavala Stop has definitely been the best product I've found for deterring my nail biting. This stuff is foul and will even be obvious if you put food in your mouth with your fingers like... eating french fries might be a chore. Just a heads up. Which is good! Sometimes having our hands near our mouths like that is an unintentional antecedent. Try to use forks and spoons for your food as much as possible.<br /><br />Good luck!at this refers to and how much of a 'trigger' those rough nail edges are. Keep all these things available,<br /><br />Next, I also take Biotin. It's a supplement- you can get it from any kind of drug store or Wal-Mart, etc. Read the bottles carefully, make sure you grab the one-a-day variety. You don't want to have to pop 3 of these a day to get your recommended dosage. Biotin helps improve nail strength- and many chronic nail biters I know have flimsy nails. Mine are definitely stronger - and my hair! So double benefit.<br /><br />Mavala Stop has definitely been the best product I've found for deterring my nail biting. This stuff is foul and will even be obvious if you put food in your mouth with your fingers like... eating french fries might be a chore. Just a heads up. Which is good! Sometimes having our hands near our mouths like that is an unintentional antecedent. Try to use forks and spoons for your food as much as possible.<br /><br />Good luck!
  911. THIS PRODUCT IS AMAZING! My son who will be 5 next month has sucked his thumb since birth. He would ALWAYS have his thumb in mouth when he woke up, during the day, at pre-school, playing, sleeping, ALWAYS! I was at first going to purchase a product called \\"thumb guard\\" but it was $80.00, so I happened to come across \\"MAVALA STOP\\" on Amazon. What a relief, the price was only $9.95 plus shipping. After reading the reviews, I was convinced this was for my little guy. I was a little hesitant because one review said there was no information in English or what the ingredients were. That is incorrect information! My bottle came in a box that had English directions and ingredients. So as a consumer I was fully informed of what I had purchased. The first day I put the MAVALA stop on his thumbs and fingers. He sucked his thumb and got a taste and he must have spit for 3 hours straight, and the stuff would get on his food. And he kept waking up in the night because he would go to suck his thumb like he always does, but the next day he only had a few \\"nasty tastes\\" and by the 3rd day, in time for school he was not sucking his thumb!!!! He has not sucked his thumb since then, and this was the boy who was \\"one with his thumb!\\" If you are going to use this to nip the thumb sucking, I recommend only putting this product on the fingernails only and not the thumb because I had to buy plastic gloves for my son to eat his food. And I would not put this on a child who cannot understand what is on their fingers and unable to talk fully with mommy or daddy. THIS STUFF IS NASTY!!! And it would be cruel to put on a child who has no understanding, in my motherly opinion. Now my little guy did throw up only once when he took this first big suck on the thumb. So be prepared and I recommend buying a sucker for licks after your little one puts their thumb in their mouth to curb the bitter taste. And have a wet wash cloth nearby to help at night when they wake up, with the \\"taste\\" on their tongue. Sorry for the long review but I really wanted to help give parents and informed decision.ste\\" on their tongue.   914. I have had a problem stress-biting my fingernails ever since college and continue into my professional career. I find myself gnawing on my fingers whenever I am thinking hard on a problem or am stressed with a deadline. I have taken to applying Mavala Stop to prevent me from this. The benefit is two-fold, first the horrible taste immediately stops me from biting my nail and second it lets me be aware of when I'm biting my nails so I can better focus on stopping. Point two is important because generally this is a sub-conscious habit that I believe I'll need to consciously break. I see noticeable improvement in my nails and in my awareness of nail-biting now, even when I haven't recently applied Mavala Stop.<br /><br />Some cons to be aware of:<br />The taste lasts for a few days, which can be problematic as you have to plan ahead to make sure there are no activities that the taste could interfere with.<br />You have to be very careful eating any sort of finger food with this on, as even the lightest touch on your lips will give you the taste and require some manner to remove it from your taste buds.<br />The taste does not come out 100% with water, and leaves me with a slightly sick feeling if I cannot get it out of my mouth due to it tasting so bad.<br /><br />Overall the cons are outweighed by the benefits and, are really necessary for what I want in the product, so I am not complaining.

  918. I'm 25, and I'd been biting my nails for roughly 20 years. I was a serious biter/picker, too. I constantly pulled at hangnails and my fingers were always red and inflamed. In reflecting on my habit, I realized that biting and picking at my nails was a sort of compulsion to make things perfect, even, and smooth. Ironically, I destroyed my nails in the process. I look back at every picture ever taken of me, and NONE of them show my hands. I either contort my hands so my nails are hidden, or I find some way to put my hands behind my back.<br /><br />Mavala has been a miracle for me. I thought I would never stop, but I did, and I couldn't have done it without this product. Now, when you have a habit like I did which was so deeply ingrained and long-standing, it will certainly take more than one try to break it. Here are my suggestions for nail-biters:<br /><br />1) Buy this or any bitter nail polish and put it on every day.<br />2) Be patient with yourself. Allow yourself to relapse and then get back on the horse. I did--multiple times :)<br />3) Stick with it--don't skip a day because you're tired of tasting bitter nail polish.<br />4) Put hand lotion (sensitive skin type, nonscented) on ALL THE TIME.<br /><br />Ultimately, leaving your nails alone is a psychological thing. Whatever it is that prompts you to manipulate your fingers needs a different outlet. Mavala makes this whole process much easier. It's like Antabuse for nail-biters.<br /><br />If you want to stop biting/picking, bitter polish is absolutely the way to go. Good luck to those who are trying to break the habit!

Nothing can get rid of it, believe me I've tried (call me weak-willed, but when I first bit them I needed to get rid of that taste, I couldn't take it). Just as a fun little story for you guys, I do this thing where I lick my nails as well. Don't really know why, I just do - take a quick swipe of them with my hand, swiping all 5 at the same time. Well, the very first day I put that stuff on I (again, absentmindedly) took a quick double swipe of my left hand...and I don't know how to describe exactly how badly that tasted. I don't have the words to describe it.<br /><br />I haven't bitten my nails at all in about a week. There is one more thing I should tell you, though. For some reason, the stuff seems to really attach itself to my lips, even though I haven't bitten in that amount of time. I can still sort of taste it if I lick my lips, and my girlfriend says that it really sucks to kiss me haha.<br /><br />All in all, a winning product after I thought nothing would work.

  943. I must share our story regarding this product. My daughter is five years old and comes from a very long line of thumb-suckers (three generations that I know of). I found two devices which are placed over the hand/thumb, and was having such a difficult time trying to choose one that I never got around to ordering either of them. Then one day my daughter came home from school and asked me if I had ordered the thumb cover to help her stop sucking her thumb. So that day, I prepared to order both devices when my husband pointed out if wearing a cast for four weeks didn't break the habit, neither will any other device we applied. He made a valid point. However after reading some of the reviews for Mavala Stop I was concerned this was too strong and bordered on \\"child abuse\\" as one reviewer put it. Even my own Mom had applied a few products to my thumb as a child, but I simply washed it off. Out of desperation we ordered it, of course tasting it before applying it to our child. But the miracle is, it worked! My daughter has not sucked her thumb since that day now five months ago. We even prepared for middle of the night awakenings (some parents recommended having juice near the bed with which to rinse out the taste) but we didn't even have those issues! The taste is unpleasant, but not so much that I would call it child abuse by any means. Some people may have a stronger reaction to this product than others, so I am not discrediting those who feel this product is too bitter. But I absolutely suggest trying it. The cost makes it a very inexpensive trial. At the risk of sounding corny: One bottle of Mavala Stop- eight dollars; Having my daughter feel proud of herself for breaking a very difficult and embarrassing habit, PRICELESS. Of course, this product is not designed to come off easily (the instructions say to apply every TWO DAYS!) so I had to figure out how to get her through the night. I finally used nail polish remover to try to remove the product from her thumbs. I'm not sure if it worked, or if my daughter was just too traumatized to put her thumb in her mouth after that, but she didn't gag or throw up again. Any time she eats anything with her fingers and gets a tast of the Mavala Stop product, she decides that she no longer likes that particular food! So, if you plan to use this on a young child, you might want to start out applying a minimal amount to the tip of the thumbnail, and be aware that the effects may be more far-reaching than you intend.
