  959. &#34;Taste the Mavalaaaa!&#34; is what my husband screams when he accidentally puts his nails in his mouth. He is a chronic nail biter who always gnaws his claws down to the quick, and so he's never had the white show on his fingernails before. After using Mavala every day for a couple of weeks, his nails were long enough that he actually needed to cut them with clippers! I was ecstatic!<br /><br />But wait! There's more! It's not just a temporary fix. After those weeks of regular use, he had become completely conditioned (read: disgusted) to stop biting his nails, even once we ceased applying the Mavala. It forced him to acknowledge his subconscious habits, and the bitter taste was unpleasant enough to deter him from idly biting his nails. Truly the miraculous cure you've been needing for you or your loved one's nail biting!<br /><br />More about this product: It comes in a nail polish-style bottle with an applicator brush in the cap. It also applies much like a clear coat nail polish, not like a thin liquid, as I originally thought it would. As such, it adheres to the nail like a glue, making it pretty difficult to wipe, lick or wash off by accident (or on purpose, muahaha). You need to use only a little bit, on the edge of your nail (if you're a biter). One application will last you the entire day, sometimes a little into day two.<br /><br />My advice for success with this product: Just remember that any bad habit dies hard. We purchased Mavala several months ago and stopped using it when my husband stopped biting. He went several bite-free months, but since then, times have been stressful at work and he occasionally relapses into nail-biting. If this happens to you, immediately go back to Mavala! Always keep it handy. Put it in your desk at work or keep it in your purse or car. Just remind yourself how horrible it tastes! You're much better off with this stuff to help you stop chewing.<br /><br />Also try applying it earlier in the day, before you go to work/school/places where you tend to bite your nails the most. Avoid eating finger foods and touching your lips (or at least be very careful)! Popcorn, pizza, sandwiches, etc. are a nightmare to eat with Mavala on. Even if you are behaving, the flavor tends to rub off on anything you touch. My husband has even given me a hello kiss after a long day at work where he struggles with biting his nails. Even THAT brief contact transferred the taste of Mavala to my lips, blegh!<br /><br />All that being said, I cannot testify to any of its other uses (such as to deter thumb sucking), but I do highly recommend it to anyone with a nail-biting problem. Be consistent, have the discipline to apply it every day, and correct yourself when you catch your bad behaviors. You will have healthy nails in no time! :)ool/places where you tend to bite your nails the most. Avoid eating finger foods and touching your lips (or at least be very careful)! Popcorn, pizza, sandwiches, etc. are a nightmare to eat with Mavala on. Even if you are behaving, the flavor tends to rub off on anything you touch. My husband has even given me a hello kiss after a long day at work where he struggles with biting his nails. Even THAT brief contact transferred the taste of Mavala to my lips, blegh!<br /><br />All that being said, I cannot testify to any of its other uses (such as to deter thumb sucking), but I do highly recommend it to anyone with a nail-biting problem. Be consistent, have the discipline to apply it every day, and correct yourself when you catch your bad behaviors. You will have healthy nails in no time! :)

I have tried it for 4 nights and applied more each night, but it did not help. This product may be helpful for those who bite their nails, but did nothing to prevent my child from sucking her thumb.
  961. 5.0 out of 5 stars Outstanding!, April 26, 2009<br />By Kristopher E. Acebo - See all my reviews<br />(REAL NAME)<br />Our daughter was 5 years old and had sucked her thumb since birth. We tried many different things to get her to stop, reward charts, painting nails with regular nail polish. When the dentist told us that if she didn't stop soon her jaw and teeth would be permanently malformed and recommended a dental device, we sought out another less expensive and less obstructive product. We applied it to both of our daughters thumbs and within a few days she had stopped sucking her thumb. Our daughter was ready and willing to stop sucking her thumb she just really needed an occasional reminder for zone out times like when watching t.v. or falling asleep. Amazing product for those kids who want to stop, but just need some extra help.

I would taste it while eating sometimes, which was just another reminder to not bite my nails. The only negative thing I have to say about my experience was that I could still bite the skin at the end of my nail bed, but that's only because nail polish doesn't stay on skin very well. It took some will power to stop biting at my skin, but after not biting my nails that skin grew over and I didn't do it anymore.   1052. I have had a lifelong struggle with nail biting. Even during times that I managed not to bite my nails, I was constantly checking them for the smallest snag or imperfection. Throughout my life I tried several different things to break the patterns, including other brands of paint-on stuff that tastes bad. Or so I thought.<br /><br />Well, Mavala is in a whole new realm of bad. The most hardened, obsessed nail-biter will recoil in horror at the taste. If your habit really stems from an underlying issue like OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder), then you may find it doesn't cure the obsessing about irregularities in your nails, but it very likely will cure the biting itself. It's just that nasty tasting. Since applying it, I no longer bite my nails.<br /><br />And yes, if you touch your mouth, you floss your teeth, you eat with your hands, etc. you're going to taste it sometimes. It's worth it til you've broken the worst of the pattern. It's also economical -- applied over dry or polished nails and cuticles, it will last days. And for any guys who may be concerned, it isn't as shiny as a typical clear nail polish, but it does have some shine to it. You can take a bit of a cloth and dab at it while it's drying to make the shine less noticeable if that's a concern.<br /><br />I'm very happy. I wish I would have discovered this 35+ years ago. It would have saved me from a lot of self-consciousness and probably a few colds.

  1059. Some may be confused by my rating for this product, but let me explain... After reading all the reviews for this product, I was so excited that I finally found something that would get my 3 year old son to stop sucking his finger. As suggested, we started with a small application on just the thumb area. I didn't want to experience any extreme adverse reactions (i.e vomiting). He stated that it wasn't \\"tasty\\" and pretty much kept it out of his mouth the entire time for that day. Later that evening when it was time for bed, he went to sleep with his thumb in his mouth as usual. The next day, we applied more but this time on a larger surface area of his thumb. He proceeded to wash it off but we kept him from doing so. Apparently, my son's taste buds wasn't too altered from this product because he sucked his thumb anyway inspite of a heavier application.<br /><br />Here is the reason for my 5-star rating: the taste is horrific! It is the worst, most bitter thing I have ever tasted. It's almost like a combination of crushed aspirin and bitter leaves or herbs. Additionally it leaves a horrible lingering taste on your tongue and lips that goes away on its time no matter how much you try and flush it with water. As one of the reviewers stated, it contaminates everything you plan to eat if you by chance use that finger to touch food. It doesn't take much at all...one slight touch and your food is ruined. Not to be gross, I even tested out the product by tasting my son's finger to see what he was experiencing (and yes, even his saliva)and it was AWFUL! I couldn't believe that it didn't phase him. I guess his thumb means that much to him. I believe this product would work if my son way younger - maybe. He's that individual who is not phased by the bitterness. I was hoping to have a different outcome to post. But I have to speak up for this product; I believe it could work if your child has a very sensitive palette. Unfortunately, this wasn't the case for my child, but I am hopeful that something will work...even if it's just time itself.eful that something will work...even if it's just time itself.

I explained both that this taste comes from the 'nail liquid' and they will not taste it if they don't bit their nails.<br /><br />I haven't seen him nor his sister biting his nails since! Not once. Even at school they noticed he stopped biting.<br /><br />Every day I asked him to show his nails, and complimented him with not biting them and how they were growing back so nicely.   1135. It's been about 2 months since I purchased this product and let me first say that I have been a nail biter for the last 20 years, since I was VERY young, about 4, but now I have stopped completely and the urge to even put my fingers CLOSE to my mouth is 100% gone. The taste is a very odd taste, sort of sweet and then like acetone... I don't even think I'm really explaining it properly but whatever it was, it was disgusting. The product is seriously amazing. I've tried other products -- EXPENSIVE salon products -- and none of them have worked. The taste wears off on other things after you wash your hands or shower, but not this. Mavala Stop lasts for a very long time, I probably only used it two-three times a week when I changed my polish.<br /><br />I bought this product in order to stop myself from biting my nails along with a product for nail growth because my nails were SEVERELY damaged. If you look at the photo on the right [my right hand] then you'll see how short my middle finger nail is. When I started using Mavala Stop I literally did NOT have a middle finger nail because I had bitten it so much and it had actually fallen off completely. Today I actually had to trim most of my nails (before this photo was taken) because they were getting too long. If you have a bad habit of biting your nails, use this. You'll never bite them again!<br /><br />TIP: Give AMPLE time for this product to dry. I used it and waited about 40 minutes before I went to bed and when I woke up the next morning I had to take the polish off because it hadn't dried properly and had creased and stuff. It felt dry to me before I'd went to bed, but I found that about an hour to an hour and a half were the best times for it to be totally dry!

  1170. Before I begin my review, a little bit of background of who was using it: I'm 23 years old now, but when I was very young I noticed my mother biting her own nails, and in my toddler mind, I thought I was supposed to mimic her, which resulted in a very fierce nail biting habit from my early childhood. I love my mother, but she had instilled within me with something of a curse.<br /><br />It was psychological for me. I've read those addicted to cigarettes have a similar issue, the \\"hand-to-mouth\\" movement. I had to bite my nails. If they were even a little long, it was too long. Obviously, I knew I had to stop, but after trying a number of products nothing ever broke the cycle. Then I found Mavala Stop.<br /><br />This was just what I needed. From the moment I put it on, I never once bit my nails again. The bitter taste it has is so incredibly intense that it outweighs even my strong urge to bite. And the worst part about it is that it lingers in your mouth for 30-60 seconds, and to me, that made me more or less think about my actions and not do it again.<br /><br />I'm proud to announce I have not bitten a nail in 4 weeks, and I've lost almost all urges to at this point.<br /><br />As for the appearance of the stuff, it dries on very shiny and I thought it looked nice. The instructions say you can paint it over nail polish.<br /><br />Bottom line: If you're looking for a fantastic non-toxic deterrent for nail biting, this is the stuff! However, user be warned. Your fingers will be BITTER. Be careful when eating finger foods! Several times I accidentally either grazed by nail on the food or touched it to my lip when I was eating and found a nasty surprise! After a while you learn how to avoid it though. The most obvious tip I can offer is to eat finger foods with a fork.

  1176. I have been trying to quit nail biting for over a decade. Everytime I about give up I look at my bloody cuticles & remember why. Before my wedding I sucessfully quit for 3 months by wearing gloves from morning to night. It wasnt a very easy task, daily things like cooking, cleaning, showers, you had to take them off and remember to put them on again. Tried this approach since & now with children it's impossible.<br />A few years ago, I had several I thought to be good bouts of non-biting after reading this book<br />http://www.amazon.com/Stop-Your-Nailbiting-Gilbreth-Brown/dp/1412023645/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1352313041&sr=1-2&keywords=stop+nail+biting.<br />I would still suggest this book as a great read on the insight of biting, made me realize its not as cut and dry as biting it's more of a OCD.<br />People who don't understand call it a nervous habit asking; \\"what are you nervous about?\\" Really?! It might have started that way, IDK I was such a young child I have no idea, then it turns into a OCD, something you do non-consciencly. That's what the book said, and I agree, but I woudld go one step further and say.. I ENJOY IT! I like the constant busy work of it, the way the nails and cuticle feel when i chew them, the way feeling afterward when I know I smoothed out that hangnail. Then I look at my hands. They are BAD, it's no wonder either.<br />----->Now to the product, after applying it less then 24 hours ago for the first time. At first I absent-mindedly put them in my mouth, this stuff in TERRIBLE! It takes any and all enjoyment out of this habit. Making you conscience of what you did & are doing with a lingering disgusting aftermath depending on how big of a hangnail you got. It tastes kinda like power steering fluid,(nail-biting is how power steering fluid ended up in my mouth, haha, the irony) I have taken a shower, done the dishes, & washed my hands at least 6 times; the stuff is still coating my nails with taste still there haunting me. I LOVE IT! I think this is finally the key! Because now I keep looking at my nails, knowing that the taste is not worth the bite. I'll let you know in a few months...<br /><br />Sorry such a long review<br /><br />UPDATE 4/14/2013<br /><br />This stuff does work!! Of course I'm still struggling with such a deep OCD but when I start to fall off the wagon, (when I'm stressed out about something) a few applications of this, spaced every 3-4 days and I'm back on track. The fluid seems to penetrate into the 'meat' of your fingers. So the deeper or more you bite the worse the punishment is. It really makes you Hate what your doing, which think about that sentence means you now fully realize when your doing it which was the first step of the battle. I have grown several sets of beautiful nails. I even got to paint them pretty for the first time in my life. My mother who has been biting for 60 years asked me for it. She likes my pretty nails. :)IT! I think this is finally the key! Because now I keep looking at my nails, knowing that the taste is not worth the bite. I'll let you know in a few months...<br /><br />Sorry such a long review<br /><br />UPDATE 4/14/2013<br /><br />This stuff does work!! Of course I'm still struggling with such a deep OCD but when I start to fall off the wagon, (when I'm stressed out about something) a few applications of this, spaced every 3-4 days and I'm back on track. The fluid seems to penetrate into the 'meat' of your fingers. So the deeper or more you bite the worse the punishment is. It really makes you Hate what your doing, which think about that sentence means you now fully realize when your doing it which was the first step of the battle. I have grown several sets of beautiful nails. I even got to paint them pretty for the first time in my life. My mother who has been biting for 60 years asked me for it. She likes my pretty nails. :)
  1177. This works and doesnt work. It's definitely bitter to the taste but it doesn't necessarily solve the problem of nail biting.
  1178. I have an 11 year old son who is way beyond just nail biting and bites his fingers as well. He's been doing this a couple of years and really wants to stop, but has had a hard time and hasn't been able to. His fingers have been red from him biting the skin off. He's been complaining about it and saying he wants to stop because it hurts and it bugs him, but he can't. He would bite his fingers not just the tips around the nails, but down the sides as well. I was hoping this would not only help him to stop, but also not hurt him when I put it on!<br /><br />IT WAS GREAT! There wasn't any stinging when I applied it (obviously there weren't any open wounds!) and he did NOT like it! By the end of the day he was saying how horrible it was because it kept making everything taste awful. :) At dinner there was an added bonus of him not eating anything with his fingers (something we're always getting on him for! :)). 2-3 days later he still had a bit on him. I haven't reapplied it yet because he's set on not biting them so he doesn't have to have this on. I LOVE it and it was worth every cent!! :)

  1186. My 2 year old child's dentist recommended this to help break a thumb-sucking habit. We found out the hard way that the bad taste (and slight numbing sensation) lingers in your mouth for *hours.* My daughter cried inconsolably for over 4 hours, refused to drink, would not swallow her saliva because of the discomfort, would not speak clearly because of the discomfort, and finally threw up. I attempted to remove the product with finger nail polish remover, then followed up with soap and water. After attempting to remove the product, I put her thumb in my own mouth so I would understand what she was experiencing. Indeed, after a single momentary exposure, and even after the attempted removal, the taste STAYS IN YOUR MOUTH for an extended period of time. After all of that, my child went right back to sucking her thumb the following day after the product wore off -- she was so exhausted after losing 5 hours of sleep, not to mention after such a horrible experience, she needed her thumb to comfort and self-soothe.<br /><br />Yes this was a strong reaction but I don't think my child was being overly dramatic. She is a middle child, her older sister is rough and tumble, and she is usually tough in the face of boo-boos and bruises.<br /><br />I can understand this product's usefulness for some individuals, such as a school age child who has unsuccessfully tried other methods, who understands how this product works, and for whom this might be a last resort. However, I was furious at our dentist for recommending this product as a first line remedy for such a young child. We are changing dentists because of this. and, clearly, not using this product again.

  1218. As far as negative reinforcement is concerned, this product is extremely effective. I HAD a 17-month-old thumbsucker who was so attached to her thumb that her top teeth were starting to buck. I had already tried several other tactics with no positive results. My brother recommended Mavala Stop, so I tried it.<br /><br />The first night was rough on my daughter (and on us), but she very quickly stopped the thumbsucking. The next day, however, she discovered her OTHER (non-treated) thumb, so I applied more Mavala. In hindsight, I probably should have just painted both thumbs from the start.<br /><br />Anyway, after reading another reviewer's comments, I had only put a tiny bit on the tip of my daughter's thumbnails. I found it didn't last long that way, so just ended up painting the entire thumbnail on both hands. Since then, I've been thrilled to see that the habit is completely gone. This product is perfect for ending thumbsucking. I couldn't be happier with the results.<br /><br />As for the cat, our 5 month old kitty was recently spayed. For some inexplicable reason the vet used dissolvable stitches and told us not to let her lick them at all for TWO WEEKS. Seriously?? They suggested a cone, but our area only sells the plastic ones and the cat wouldn't be able to eat, drink, sleep, or even get into her little house bed with it on, so that wasn't an option. The vet also suggested a premie &#34;onesie.&#34; We went with that option, but it's been less than ideal as it rides up unless it's snapped shut at the butt and then the cat can't use the bathroom. The snaps go over her butt, so cutting a hole there for toileting needs would be the same as not snapping it shut at all. But, we tried the onesie without snapping it shut and just watched her as much as possible. Predictably, she wouldn't stop licking and chewing at the incision. By day 5, my youngest daughter happened to see the cat chewing at her incision. She went to stop her when the cat raised its head and &#34;looked like she was eating something.&#34; Super. While the incision looks normal, I'm pretty sure she managed to pull out at least some of her surface stitches. We next tried to rig up a homemade soft collar to stop her injuring herself, but that didn't work well either and only lasted a few minutes.<br /><br />Frustrated, I finally remembered we had an almost-full bottle of Mavala Stop and wondered if it would be safe to use on a cat. I checked every ingredient first to ensure there was nothing that could be toxic to kitty (there wasn't) and decided to give it a try. NOTE: I only used a VERY tiny amount of this stuff and did NOT rub it on the incision. We also did NOT use it when her incision was fresh, but waited until day 5 when the wound was crusting over (and probably itching) and the cat was obsessively attending to it. At that point, I dipped a medical grade swab into the Mavala Stop container, wiped off the excess on the bottle's edge, and then very, very lightly and gently ROLLED the swab along the incision--just enough so that if she licked that area again, she'd get a light taste that might stop her from wanting to lick there any more. Then we waited.<br /><br />Pretty soon the cat licked her incision. I thought the effort was another failure until the cat immediately went to her water bowl and drank a lot of water. Shortly afterwards, she again bent down to lick the incision. This time, however, she froze in mid-movement for a few seconds, seemed to remember the unpleasant experience of a few moments ago, and continued walking without licking or chewing the area again. She did that a second time soon afterwards but, again, froze in mid-movement and did not lick her incision. Two days later and we have not seen her lick or chew the stitches/incision again. She seems completely healthy and isn't any worse for wear. We have not applied Mavala Stop more than that one time and, as I stated, only used a very, very light amount--just so a bit of the nasty taste would be there to stop her licking and chewing. So far, it seems to have resolved the problem.nt--just so a bit of the nasty taste would be there to stop her licking and chewing. So far, it seems to have resolved the problem.

No imagine constantly being shown videos of employees spiting in food, rats running around the kitchen, and a bunch of other disgusting things going on in the kitchen. This stuff worked so well for me, I only needed to use if for about a month. I have put it on once in the past few weeks. Even then I really didn't need it. My nails look great. In fact I have half to two thirds of the bottle left! Put it on your finger and taste, it is nasty. So expect some crying on reflex sucking the first few days. It doesn't hurt or burn, it is just a really undesirable taste. I wonder what they put in there.
  1433.   1434. I have bad nail-biting habit at age 26. But this product tastes so bad, and lingers for very long, that I quickly became averted to putting my fingers in my mouth. At first, you'll realize just how involuntary that action is, and eventually you'll stop doing it because of the horrible taste. I have so far been successful in not biting my nails since I bought this. Stick with it and you'll have the same results. Couple notes:<br /><br />-The bottle recommends putting it on every other day, which I will say is accurate. It will usually last through the next day.<br />-The supply appears to last a good few months<br />-This product will ruin flossing for you. It is impossible not to taste it while flossing. Very unpleasant.<br />-Same with finger foods. You'll need to be very careful eating them<br /><br />If nothing else can make you stop biting, give this product a try.

  1461. I've been chewing my nails for over 30 years. I've tried to quit many times, and used other \\"bitter tasting\\" products on my nails that never worked because the taste was just not enough to override my compulsion to chew my nails.<br /><br />As an adult now studying to go into a law enforcement profession where bad nails can be a vector for infection and disease-transmission, I NEED to stop doing this or I put my life at risk. Malava Stop works for me. It's been a month since I chewed my nails and I'm starting to use nail polish and nail care products seriously for the first time in my life (OMG I'm going to become a nail polish freak).<br /><br />To say that this stuff tastes bad doesn't even come close. It's NOT hot/spicy like pepper, and is hard to describe, but your reaction to it is immediate and visceral (\\"UGGHHH that was a bad idea\\"). The best part about it is that the taste LINGERS. It isn't something that's momentarily bitter and then stops. If you make the mistake of sticking a finger in your mouth, you will remember it for HOURS afterward. In this respect it works like behavioral conditioning at the animal level.<br /><br />I would suggest switching to a fork for eating while using this product, as the taste does interfere with eating foods with your bare fingers. Even if you remove the product (such as if a child deliberately strips the stuff off as soon as you're out of sight), you will still taste it strongly for at least a day or two. So if you're using this on your kids to stop them from nail biting, they won't be able to remove the product to get rid of the taste.<br /><br />This product, like anything of its type, works best in combination with willpower and a commitment to stop chewing your nails.

  1464. I am a nurse and was wary of trying a product that contained chemicals, but nothing else had worked to date. I have a 4 year old and 6 year old who sucked their thumbs.   1546. This product is amazing! I have been chewing on my cuticles for at least 10 years and have never had anything work like Mavala does!<br /><br />I used to chew on my cuticles CONSTANTLY throughout the day, which left my fingers bleeding, raw, and horrible to look at by the end of every day. In fact, I envied people who chewed on their nails because their fingers looked light years better than mine did! I didn't realize half the time when I was chewing on them, which definitely makes it hard to break the habit. At first I tried to have my boyfriend and other friends just stop me when they saw me, but they can't watch me all the time, and I just got really good at waiting for them to stop looking. After trying some other creative ways of breaking the habit, I decided to purchase Mavala Stop to see if it would deter me from putting my fingers near my mouth. Did it ever! The taste is NASTY (which is great for reminding you to stop) and it lingers for a while on your lips and tongue afterward for at least a few minutes. This is great for me because it just reinforces the lesson even after, which means I am less likely to attempt to chew again. I swear I would try to convince myself that it wasn't so bad, but when you have the taste still on your lips for a while there is not way to deny that is it gross. I am proud to say that my cuticles are healing up wonderfully and I am less likely now to try to put my fingers in my mouth. There is enough nail polish in the bottle to last you until you have permanently broken the habit too, so you don't need to worry about a temporary fix and then when you run out falling back in the habit. The polish is not very noticeable either, just a little shiny at first and then dulls after a day or so.<br /><br />A few things to note though: The first day I used this product, I put a lot of it on and all over my cuticles just for safe measure. I don't put any more on my cuticles just because it was too much, but it was a great shock factor to teach me not to do it any more. I would say though be careful with children because it will be REALLY bad if they put their whole nail in their mouths without realizing it. The taste also lingers on your lips if you touch them (which is really disgusting while eating food), so be careful when you freshly apply the stuff. And for adults, slather it on every 2 days with someone else to watch you, since it would be easy to \\"forget\\" to put it on without a support system to make sure you follow through. Seriously though, I carry this stuff in my purse and I have not had a problem! I dread the thought of chewing my cuticles cause I know I will get a nasty taste in return!<br /><br />This product would probably also work for kids who has issues putting different stuff in their mouths (fingers, boogers, blankets, toys, etc) or with pets chewing on things. The 5 year old continued thumb sucking for four days while using this product on just the nail. However, applying a larger glob to cover some skin area too had a more dramatic effect when the thumb was sucked; There was coughing for about 5 minutes, some gagging, minor throw up, but now thumb sucking is finally beginning to stop with just that one heavier application. For a 3 year old, coating only the nail was plenty to cause gagging and some minor throw up, and the child hasn't sucked thumb since. The direction call for coating nail every other day, but it may require coating once or twice a day depending on how much they have sucked. For those worried about night time unconscious sucking, place a sock over hand or some type of thumb-guard to prevent thumb sucking while sleeping to prevent gagging at night.<br /><br />In summary, my opinion is to start with just a thin coat on the nail or part of the nail every other day per instructions, but be ready to move to coating everyday and/or thicker and larger area if you find your child continues to thumb suck.   1563. We bought this product to help our 5 yr old stop sucking his thumb. Our son was an avid thumb sucker at night and occasionally throughout the day.<br /><br />We researched products out there and this one received the best reviews. After trying the product for about 2 days, it worked! Our son had no desire to suck his thumb.. We continued to use the product for about 3 weeks as directed to ensure no setbacks... It's now been about 2 months and our son has not once tried to suck his thumb...<br /><br />Tips:<br />1. Apply as directed. We applied this at night when he was sleeping. He had no idea it was us that was applying the \\"magic sprinkles\\" as he called them on his thumbs. If he knew it was us, he would have resisted. We told him the tooth fairy must have sprinkled magic dust on his thumbs to help him stop sucking his thumbs...<br />2. Make sure you apply the liquid to all fingers (at the base of the nail not the tips). After the first day we noticed our son trying to suck other fingers when the thumbs didn't taste good. ... We corrected that after a 2nd doses on all fingers!<br /><br />Can't say enough good things about this product. It tastes awful but it works and that was our goal! Highly recommend it.

This stuff is beyond gross tasting. I would find myself starting to bite my nails while I was doing something and BAM that taste would hit my mouth and I would immediately become aware of what I was doing and stop. There is just no way you can keep biting your nails with this stuff on them. You will have to stop because if you don't you will become physically ill. It's been a month since I bought it and for the most part I have stopped. I still find myself trying to nip at something here and there but as soon as I do, BAM, that awful taste kicks in and I stop. The only negative about the stuff is that if you love finger foods like fried chicken then you better be careful. No licking your fingers or you will be in trouble.   1593. This stuff tastes absolutely horrible.<br />Sadly, it still didn't work for me, but then again, neither did spraying my fingertips with pepper spray (I bit my nails through that! yikes!).<br />Of the millions of products like this I have tried, this is the nastiest one I've encountered.<br />One thing to consider is that when you eat things with your hands, like a sandwich, you sometimes get some of the taste of this in your mouth. You have to be careful not to!<br /><br />Advice for nail-biters (unrelated to the product) : I got acrylic nails on top of my severely bitten nails (down to the cuticles). Every couple weeks, I would go back to the nail salon to get them \\"filled.\\" (They put the acrylic liquid stuff at the base of your nail, where it has grown out. It hardens to blend in with the rest of your acrylic nail. Then they do a regular manicure: trimming the nails, painting, etc.).<br />Many months later, my real nails were the same length as the acrylics on top of them! I let them fall off, and my nails were so damaged they were BENDY, rough, and jagged. I could literally bend the tip of my nail in half. This made me want to bite them, of course. So, I trimmed them down - as hard as it was to see my first-time natural long nails cut - filed and buffed them, then painted them with a light pink polish. Eventually, I was able to stop painting them and not have the urge to bite them. Now, I keep a nail filer and buffer with me at ALL times to fix any jagged parts throughout the day. My nails are now long, healthy, and they grow really fast.<br />So, if this product doesn't work for you (as nasty as it is!), I'd advise doing what I did - minus the pepper spray!

  1613. I have been a nail biter most of my life and I wanted to stop. I tried everything I could think of to try to stop biting my nails. And this is something I would do subconsciously. I would do this while sitting watching tv, reading a book, magazine or computer and when I am bored.<br /><br />Enter Mavala Stop. I would sit here on Amazon and other websites reading reviews and just about every review I would read raved about this product for helping them quit biting their nails or keeping their children from sucking their thumbs and fingers. I had my doubts reading these reviews but I decided to take the plunge.<br /><br />I got this product on Monday, right after Easter, and applied this product. I forgot I had this product on my fingers and put them to my mouth. The taste. OH THE TASTE!!!! I'd swear the same sadists that created &#34;The One Ring<br />' in the bowels of Mordor, created the taste of this product (those that have watched &#34;The Lord of the Rings&#34; movies or read the books will get this reference). It is the most vile, horroble bitter taste I have ever tasted. The taste sticks to the inside of your mouth and stays there for a long time. There is nothing you can do to get the taste out of your mouth once its there. Plus, not only does the taste stick to your mouth and tongue, it sticks to your lips and around your mouth. So anytime you lick your lips or anywhere surrounding your mouth, you get that taste as well only not quite as strong. As far as how well the product lasts, it seems to have some staying power but leads to one of my complaints about the product. It seems to have a weakness to soap when you get a bath or wash your hands. It knocks the taste of the product down a good bit, especially after getting a bath. So if you reapply this after getting a bath, you should be good. If you can spare getting soap on your fingernails though the bad taste does seem to last but does get somewhat weaker over time.<br /><br />I can't speak to how the product works on children, but I can speak for an adult and this product does work. I have been using the product for a week and after that first day, I have rarely put my fingers to my mouth as I don't want to taste that taste in my mouth. It does effect eating snacks like popcorn and potato chips as well as eating finger foods. But now, I don't bite my nails, and for that...this product is a really good thing.<br /><br />In closing, if you are a nail biter and you want to quit? Please, I implore you... get this product. Yes, it tastes horrible and nasty but it works wonders. If it can help someone who has bit their nails for the last 33 years plus then it will help you, too.duct works on children, but I can speak for an adult and this product does work. My husband also used it as he is a nail biter and he hasn't touched his nails since using it!   1646. PROS:<br />Very effective<br /><br />CONS:<br />Too effective. Yes you read that right. This thing works exactly as advertised and within 4 days, I have pretty much stopped biting my nails. So why is this a con? Well thats because you can't use your fingers to eat any food at all. This is probably not a problem for most people but I am an Indian, so there is a lot of bread or rice that we eat with our bare hands, so if this thing accidentally touches your food, well you can say good bye to good taste. I have tried eating normal food (e.g. cut fruits or chips).with my fingers as well. Again, if this even remotely touches that food from your fingers, you are done for.<br /><br />Just something to bear in mind when you are using this product..

She is proud to show how her fingers are healing now.   1722. My son just got used to the flavor. If your kid is sensitive to tastes, maybe this will work for you.
  1723. My son's will is stronger than the awful taste of this stuff. It worked at first, and then he didn't care.
  1724. I would strongly recommend this product. I have been a professional nail biter since before I can remember, with more cuticle infections then I can count. This stuff tastes absolutely terrible, so it works. :)<br />I bite my nails, and the skin/cuticle area around my nails, so I ended up having to basically paint the top parts of my fingers.<br />Realistically, this product deserves five stars because it does the job, at least for me. However, the taste of the nail polish is easily transferred to other things like finger foods (chips etc.). Part of the issue is quite likely that I had to paint the entire front tips of my fingers (most definitely the problem). So for me, finger foods were simply out of the question. I would suggest 2-3 coats of polish. The first couple days were rough, and I constantly had a terrible taste in my mouth, but each day got a little better. Now I can actually see the start of nail growth, so yay for me.<br /><br />It tastes disgusting, but suck it up, buy it, stick with it, and eat with a fork.

He licked his fingers and true to form he shrugged it off like &#34;No big deal&#34; He ended up playing in the water with friends about an hour later and it came off. I was very optimistic that it would work. The first time my son put his thumb in his mouth after application, he immediately pulled his thumb out, making a horrible face. I was so excited! Then the next morning while driving to daycare, I saw my son sucking his thumb. At the first stop light I got to- I reached back and sucked his thumb- it still tasted bitter. By the end of the day- the bitter taste on his finger was gone. My son had sucked it off. Giving this product two stars, because I think it would work on adults who want to break a bad habit- but doesn't do any good for a toddler who is adicted to his thumb.   1731. As intended, this product has finally brought an end to my lifelong nail biting habit. Bitter, repulsive, and lingering are words that can be used to describe this product if it manages to reach your mouth. It only took a few days of this for me to gain an awareness of my nail biting and this awareness has enabled me to stop biting my nails. I have stopped myself numerous times raising my fingers to my mouth, haunted by the memories of previous encounters with Mavala Stop in my mouth and on my lips. Did I mention the taste of this product lingers? It will terrorize your taste buds for at least 20 minutes and is nearly impossible to get the taste out.<br /><br />If you cook frequently, make sure to wear gloves at all times when using Mavala Stop! I have ruined a couple of meals by forgetting that I had applied this product to my nails and the entire dish was ruined. This stuff is extremely potent and will easily taint food if prepared with bare hands.<br /><br />I really wish I had the willpower to stop biting my nails without the aid of a horrible tasting product but I don't so this product was a last resort for me. I was applying them about every 2 or 3 weeks and would do so when I saw her putting her fingers in her mouth.<br /><br />It's been 13 months now. It's very rare that she puts her fingers in her mouth and when I do, I put Mavala on her nails. I believe that after another year of applying this, she will be able to stop.   1799. After trying the \\"Thum Thumb\\" brand from the local drugstore to no avail. I decided to purchase this and give it a try. It is nasty, but it doesn't hurt or burn or anything like that, just leaves you with a nasty taste in your month for a few seconds. I put it on my son the next day, just on the 2 fingers he sucks, I told him it was medicine for his nails (which look ragged and thin because of all the sucking!) He just stuck his fingers in his mouth without thinking, and then out they came! At night time he fell asleep quickly without even \\"testing\\" if the fingers still tasted bad. The next day at nap he asked if there was still medicine on his hand, I said there was, and it didn't taste good, so he should try not to put them in his mouth. He must have believed me, because again he just went to sleep without them! I reapplied every couple of days for 2 weeks and he never even asks about it or trys to use his fingers anymore. Habit forgotten without a struggle! Defiantly recommend! Keep in mind though if your child eats with his hand he will get a bad taste in his his mouth while using this. Never affected my son since he sucked his middle and ring finger, which he doesnt use to eat. However it got me a couple times that first day when I licked my fingers while preparing dinner, so becareful and encourge the use of silverware while using.my son since he sucked his middle and ring finger, which he doesnt use to eat. However it got me a couple times that first day when I licked my fingers while preparing dinner, so becareful and encourge the use of silverware while using.

  1829. Our 4-year-old was a MAJOR thumb-sucker, she did it all throughout the day as well as at night. I tried rewards, sticker charts, etc. because I was trying to avoid going a &#34;harsh&#34; route, but none of that worked. So finally, I was trying to decide between Mavala and a thumb guard (I knew people who had had success with each one), and Mavala was much cheaper so I decided to try it first. I am SO GLAD I did because the first day, after lots of talk about being such a big girl, a fun reward if she stopped, etc. I put it on her favorite thumb.... so she sucked her other thumb. I put it on her other thumb, then she started sucking her pointer finger... put it on that finger, and so on, until she had it on all 10 fingers (she even tried sucking her baby brother's thumb once!) I am really glad I used Mavala instead of a thumb guard because in hindsight, if I'd gotten a thumb guard, she would've just sucked her other fingers! Also, since she is 4 and not younger, I think the Mavala was nice because no one else was aware of it (whereas, a thumb guard, her friends would've noticed and asked about it, and I'm not sure she would have done as well emotionally with it -- because it was very emotional for her to give it up --- if it had been so public). I applied it once every 2 days, and am STILL applying it almost 7 weeks later because if it comes off and she is really tired and watching tv, riding in the car, etc. she will try to suck whichever finger doesn't have any. So this has not been a really quick-fix, like 3 days and we're done, it's an ongoing process, but I have been very pleased with the result. It was MUCH less emotionally taxing for me than when I was reminding her 50 times a day, offering stickers, etc. This was simpler and I didn't have to nag and stay on top of it, other than applying it every other day. I would HIGHLY recommend this!! And I will use it with my son, who is only 1 year old and is a finger-sucker, when he is older (it says ages 3 and up).

I used nail polish remover, just like the instruction booklet says, but it was not very effective. Both kids still looked visibly disgusted the next day when their fingers touched their lips, and I assume it was because the product is so strong. I placed a small amount on my thumb, and then after about 5 seconds used a towel to try to wipe it off. 9 hours later (including a shower along with washing dishes, and scrubbing at it), my thumb still tastes VERY BAD! By very bad, I mean water is not strong enough to wash the taste out of my mouth....I needed soada to remove the bitter taste! It even still lasted to morning! This product is fantastic!
  1980. This stuff is so great! I have a compulsive thumbsucker who's 6. His permanent teeth just started coming in and as a childhood thumbsucker myself, I didn't want him ending up with an overbite like I did. After doing some research, we ordered Mavala Stop and he quit sucking his thumb completely as soon as it dried. I put some on my finger with him the first time and it tasted TERRIBLE. Even after a shower and a nights sleep! After a week, we lost the bottle. We tried THUM (another stop sucking polish) and it did not work at all. I think he actually liked the taste. He asked us to reorder the STOP because he wants to quit sucking his thumb (now that hes a \\"big boy\\"). We're back on the Mavala with NO problems. This stuff is like liquid gold for frustrated parents!!
  1981. I've tried a couple different products to stop nail biting and this stuff is by far the best one I've used. It tastes horrible and an application lasts for days. I put this on for the first time about 5 days ago and it's still working. I expect that after about a month or two of using this I'll have broken the habit. If you are going to use this and you like finger food watch out. It makes most things that you eat with your hands taste terrible as well.
  1982. I had serious doubts that this product would work for my nearly 7 year old, but it did the trick! She finally stopped sucking her thumbs!
  1983. Took one day,<br />(tried positive reinforcement/rewards for 6 months with no successs)<br />Prepped our child for its arrival. Let her know she is big now and that she had to stop and we had medicine to help her. Let her apply it to her nails since she is so big (never let her touch medicine so this was a big treat). On the 1st night we both tasted a very very very small amount. It is very bitter. She woke twice the 1st night after putting her thumb in her mouth. Applied it to the nails over the next 1 to 1.5 weeks but she never sucked her thumb after the 1st night.<br /><br />other things we learned:<br />only apply it to the nail and wrap the bottle in a tissue. The smallest drop will work its way to your child's mouth.<br />If they do get it in their mouth. Make sure the cup or sippy they drink from to clean their mouth out is also cleaned or change after drinking. The cup will get the product on it, therby continuing the taste in their mouth.<br />Finally, toothpaste was the best to get the taste out.<br />The taste for our child was not horrible just annoyong and letting her apply it empowered her to be able to stop sucking her thumb by herself.<br /><br />Good Luck.

  1989. My son is 2 years old and has been sucking his thumb since he found it as a baby. I really wanted to break this habit and have been trying for a year now. I tried all the things I read about and nothing worked. I did not want to wait any longer with hearing the horror stories of dental problems from friends that had kids that sucked their thumbs. I tried tobasco sauce on the thumbs and it was just a taste that would stop him for a minute and then it would go away and he would have his thumb right back in his mouth. I found an article about Thum and foud that many people said it didn't work and that their children started to like the taste and I thought then it couldn't be any better than the tobasco sauce and then I found this product. I will admit when you first put it on and your child tries to suck his thumb it is hard to see him gag and his mouth water from the taste. But I gave him a drink and let him get the taste out of his mouth and he has tried once more in the week and a half of using this stuff. I put it on once every three days so far and it seems to be working. I really thought I would never break him of this habit, if he was not eating one of his thumbs were almost always in his mouth while the other was playing with his toy or whatever he was doing. It really does work, you just have to be willing to see your child the first time or two gag for a minute when they get that taste in their mouth. I am hoping to only use this about another week and hopefully I won't have to put it on ever again!!!!
  1990. We bought this for our 2 year old granddaughter who had sucked her thumb since birth.   1991. I have never written a review before, but I said to myself if this stuff works I will write a review so it would help other mothers. I have a 3 1/2 year old daughter who literally has been sucking her thumb since she was in the whomb! Any time she was tired or upset she would suck her thumb and twirl her hair. I honestly thought I would never get her to stop. I thought my only hope was to buy the thumbguard, but that is expensive and I thought she probably wouldn't wear it anyhow. So for $7.99 I found this recommendation on Baby Center.com. I bought it here on Amazon and tried it the day we received it. I told her it was special nail polish just for her. I made up an excuse as to why I was only applying it to her thumbs, but she didn't care. A few minutes later she went to put her thumb in her mouth and took it out a split second later. She told me it tasted funny and I just told her she shouldn't suck her thumb anyway. Well, its been over a week now and no thumb sucking!! It really is amazing. I've only had to apply it a couple of times just for precaution, but really it wasn't even necessary. I would recommend this product to everyone with a child who sucks their thumb. If my daughter the queen of thumbsucking can stop, anyone's child can!

  1997. I have been biting my nails for 35 years. I have tried many different ways to stop, including hypnosis. None Worked. THIS DOES! I have now not bitten my nails in over 6 weeks. Even if I have forgotten to put it on for a couple days, every time I go to put my fingers in my mouth, some kind of reverse Pavlov's dog effect happens and I just remember how NASTY this stuff tastes and how it lingers in your mouth and I end up not biting my nails. YES, it tastes gross..that's the point. Yes, if you eat with your fingers, you will end up tasting this stuff with whatever you eat. But bottom line is...it SIMPLY WORKS!!

  2013. I almost purchased this product... I mean the reviews are stellar. It sounds like it really works and I wanted to buy it. Interestingly I didn't see reviews that questioning the safety of this product.<br /><br />I researched only the first ingredient, \\"Ethyl Acetate,\\" and here's is just a tiny excerpt of what I found on the osha.gov website...<br /><br />\\"Affects on Animals: Ethyl acetate is a respiratory tract irritant and, at high concentrations, it causes narcosis and depression of heart function [Hathaway et al. 1991]. The oral LD(50) for acute exposure to ethyl acetate is 4,935 mg/kg for rabbits and 5,620 mg/kg for rats; and the 8-hour rat inhalation LC(50) is 1600 ppm [Sax and Lewis 1989].\\"<br /><br />That's all I needed to see. You can read the rest of the article here:<br />[...]<br />I love my kid too much to risk using this crap, even if it does work.

  2019. My 3 year old daughter has been pulling her hair and sucking her thumb since she was about six months. When she was 18 months my husband and I made the difficult decision to cut all of her hair off in order to break the habit. The hair pulling stopped, and even when it started to grow again she didn't return to pulling. However, the thumb sucking problem never stopped despite all the different things we tried. About 2 months ago, while watching tv, I saw my daughter reach up, pull some hair out and proceed to suck her thumb. Needless to say, I freaked out, and instantly started searching for something to help stop the thumb sucking once and for all. Their experience was identicle to my daughter's situation. So I purchased it. And I am truly thankful for that review and this product. Mavala Stop was an absolute miracle. I explained to my daughter that it was time for her to be a big girl and that this special polish was going to help her do that. She let me put it on and was really excited. As she was going to bed she attempted to suck her thumb and was completely taken back by the taste. I quickly explained &#34;I know it doesn't taste good, and every time you put your thumb in your mouth it's going to be nasty. I still apply it to her thumbs every two days because I don't want the possibility of a relapse. I wish I could give Mavala Stop 20 stars.

  2031. So far, this product has worked well. It leaves an extremely bitter taste whenever you put your fingers in your mouth. The taste lasts for about 1 minute. The only downside (being a male) is that it has a slightly glossy finish.
  2032. My 5 year old daughter was motivated to break the thumb sucking habit, unfortunately her thumb went into her mouth reflexively all the time and she wasn't having much success with other methods and reminders. I purchased this on the recommendation of a friend and painted my own thumb and stuck it in my mouth. I almost retched into the sink. It tastes like ear wax times 40. I told my daughter she would be disgusted by the taste. She was motivated so she held out her hand. The stuff goes on clear, dries totally and lasts about 3 days, so you reapply every three days. They say it takes 21 days to break a habit. My daughter was done sucking her thumb in 2 days! The first day she put her thumb in her mouth without thinking over a dozen times, each time ripping it back out and spluttering a little. Once she started to make the association with the aversive taste, she stopped sucking her thumb. I did apply the Mavala stop every few days for almost 3 weeks just to make sure we didn't have a relapse. She was sooo proud of herself for breaking the habit and so happy with herself once she realized she didn't need her thumb any more. Of course, I rewarded her with a pony. (American Girl pony, that is!). You probably shouldn't try this with real little kids, and it will probably be more successful if the child is motivated to top sucking. One thing you should be aware of is that after you apply this, if the child eats finger foods they could get some of the taste co-mingling with the food. This is why I am hesitant to try it with my next daughter to break her of her nail biting habit. I would have to apply to all the nails, so not sure how it will go over at mealtime.

  2035. ATTENTION! Important! I tried it myself before putting it on my 4-yr-old daughter, which is good because I found that you need to apply just A VERY TINY BIT TO THE BASE OF THE THUMBNAIL. This way, they'll taste it when they suck their thumbs, but they won't accidentally taste it when they eat fingerfoods. It has a horrible, bitter-taste that stays in your mouth (eating food or drinking a flavored drink helps the taste go away). It has been at least 3 months since my daughter stopped sucking her thumb! Hallelujah. I wouldn't say it just \\"helped\\" her stop thumbsucking, it \\"made\\" her stop sucking her thumbs. I gave some of it to a friend, and her daughter was also able to stop over a very short period of time. Anyway, to summarize I told my daughter that the Tooth Fairy knows how important good teeth are and that she makes kids' thumbs taste bad when she feels they're a big girl/boy to help them stop sucking their thumbs. She was excited about it happening. Then, I painted the polish on while she was sleeping. Long story short, she hated the taste so much that I didn't even have to paint it on again (taste lasts for 2-3 days). She was done with it. I'm not saying it wasn't challenging for her, but now she doesn't even think about it anymore. After it works for your child, let others know, so their kids can be helped by it. My daughter's teeth quickly looked noticeably better and moved back in quite a bit. Pretty cool, eh!? I was worried before I tried it because she used her thumb so much for comfort, but she did great, and your kid will too. Try it, and then share the leftovers (there will be plenty) with others who need it.

My one year old son, didn't suck his thumb, but he was chewing all the skin off the ends of his fingers..to the point of bleeding. I used this sutff on all three of them, and it has worked wonderfully. I used it for two weeks, and then gradually tapered off. None of them have sucked or chewed since then.<br />I know it's disgusting, but like so many kids some of them are also nose pickers. YUCK! And we all know where they put their fingers after they come out of their nose. Right into their mouth. Again...YUCK! I decided to try it and see if it would help with that problem as well, and it does. It doesn't burn their nose, like I was afraid it might, and they don't dare put their fingers into their mouth. Apparently without that, picking their nose isn't quite as much fun.<br />I have referred countless people to this product, including adults who were trying to quit nail-biting. Success for them as well.<br />All I can say, is this product is worth it's weight in gold! And it's a whole lot cheaper than braces!
  2044. Whew...one taste and you definitely won't want to put your fingers in your mouth. GROSS!<br />My 5 year old son bites his nails. After I put this on his nails he unconsciously put a finger in his mouth...what happened next was definitely bittersweet...he started crying and promising me he wouldn't bite his nails anymore. The taste is horrible. I know, because I put it on one of my nails just to see how bad it really was. I want to relate this to &#34;cruel and unusual punishment&#34;; however, it should do the job of keeping nails from being bitten.
  2045. This product tastes very bitter (which is a good thing) but the taste doesn't go away for hours. And if my daughter dips her thumb in milk or water or any other food the whole thing gets bitter and can't be eaten. Not very happy with the product.

  2134. My 3.5 year old daughter sucks her thumb so much -- including while asleep -- that the dentist said she had begun to deform her mouth. Applying this every two days has eliminated her thumbsucking going into week two. I was amazed at how fast it worked. It tastes so horrible that she doesn't even such her thumb while asleep. Having said that, I think if the child is older they would figure out how to scratch the coating off or otherwise remove it. But with a young child, it works really well. I'm going to keep this up for 60 days and see if the habit is broken. So far so good.<br /><br />UPDATE.... well, after about two weeks, my daughter figured out how to scratch this stuff off. I explained to her that she shouldn't suck her thumb anymore if she wanted to avoid a repeat of the experience, and she quit IMMEDIATELY! It's six months later now and she hasn't gone back to sucking. I've been doing it for 25+ years and have half hazardously tried to stop several times to no avail.<br /><br />I think it's important to note that just using the nail polish to kick the habit probably isn't going to be enough. When I was younger my parents tried all these nasty polishes and I just kept trying until the bitter taste finally subsided. I was determined to keep biting so their efforts were never enough. It's important that the nail biter WANTS to quit. This is just a tool to help aid in reminding you to reach the goal of quitting. Using it without the true desire to stop will probably not be enough.<br /><br />This polish tastes similar to hand sanitizer but the chemical taste lingers for several minutes longer. A glass of water will make the taste disappear.<br /><br />This product IS shiny and not matte. However, after 2-3 days it will lose it's shine. For me, the taste sticks around well after a few days primarily because I have been making a conscious effort not to bite. It's been about a week and I think this product has helped but I still have quite a ways to go before I can say I've kicked the habit.

While she was fast asleep, I put just BARELY a little on. Sure enough, she woke up crying, saying her thumb didn't taste good, almost threw up...but eventually I calmed her and reminded her that the fairy came. And she was happy, and acknowledged that she must be growing up. In less than a week, she stopped. My bottle was barely used!!!
  2292. Terrible taste is perfect.<br /><br />It does wash off quickly.<br /><br />I needed something to remind me to keep my fingers out of my mouth and this is perfect. I don't always realize that I am putting my hands in my mouth. It's a very absentminded habit. With the Mavala, I don't pick at the nails, bite them, or use my fingers to pick at my teeth. Overall I am very please so far and this was way less expensive and cumbersome than those thumb guard contraptions. The result was about ten minutes of washing my mouth out, and about an hour of regret. I can still recall vividly the situation, months later.<br /><br />However, this is only the first step in stopping to bite your fingernails. As long as you wear this nail polish, you won't bite them. However, if you don't use the time to build up good habits of cutting them, you will go right back to biting them as soon as you stop. I made the poor choice of having my fingernail scissors in a difficult to get to location. I almost immediately regressed back into fingernail biting. I have enough control due to the substance that I have been able to use scissors most of the time now that I have relocated them, but I still bite my nails occasionally.<br /><br />A note of warning, if you like to lick your fingers after eating popcorn or chips, you will not be able to for the entire duration of this treatment.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Works, if used correctly<br /><br />Cons:<br />Can fail to work if good habits aren't put in place<br /><br />neutral facts:<br />Tastes AWFUL<br />will not be able to put fingers near mouth for any reason<br />you eventually get a little bit used to the taste due to small amounts getting near lips or on things that go in your mouth.

  2399. Our four-year-old son has sucked his thumb since day one. We are very concerned about this and have tried various methods to get him to stop.<br />After reading the many glowing reviews of this product on this and other websites, we decided to try it.<br /><br />The first thing we noticed about the product we received was that it looked and smelled like acetone or nail polish remover. Alarmed, we contacted our dentist and pediatrician, both of whom advised us that the smell comes from solvents in the product which evaporate after application and should not pose a risk. With some trepidation, we decided to try the product anyway. The next things we noticed were that the product seemed to wear off rather quickly with our son and that he was willing to put up with the residual taste at prime thumb-sucking time (such as when he was tired).<br /><br />Concerned about the frequency of application required, we then contacted the FDA Center for Drug Evaluation and Research to see if they had any information about the product. The FDA informed us it has not evaluated the product for safety or efficacy and advised us to submit a MedWatch Report for possible follow-up investigation. The official who responded to our inquiry seemed concerned about the solvents and alcohol that form the main ingredients of this product.<br /><br />Note that the FDA official did not indicate that the product was necessarily dangerous. However, the official did seem to think that further investigation was warranted. For the record, our son does not seem to have suffered any ill effects after 4 days of use.<br /><br />My son was recently promoted to the \\"big kids\\" class at his pre-school, and we're very anxious about the physical and social effects of his thumb-sucking. We're as eager as anyone to find a magic bullet to fix this problem, but we have concluded that using alcohol and solvents of unknown efficacy and safety is too high a risk. Note too that because the product is made in Switzerland, holding its makers accountable for any adverse effects that might occur would be difficult. Before using this product, you may want to ask yourself whether you want your kids to be guinea pigs for the untested products of a foreign chemical company.tzerland, holding its makers accountable for any adverse effects that might occur would be difficult. Before using this product, you may want to ask yourself whether you want your kids to be guinea pigs for the untested products of a foreign chemical company.

The wrapper was damp from condensation and the taste got on the plastic and I ingested it. Water did not wash it away. Gum worked okay. She had to learn to eat food with her other hand to avoid touching her thumb to her food or her face. I refresh it with one brush stroke after day 3 - I no longer paint her entire nail.<br /><br />3)If you have a small child (3 or under), start with a small amount and assess the affect before jumping in and painting the entire fingernail. You can always add more...but it isn't easy to take it off. Personally, the taste is bad enough that I don't think I would have applied this product to a child that was under 2.5 or 3. Not to criticise anyone who does, but my children are tiny and making sure they got enough daily nutrition was of concern to me at that age. I wouldn't want to jeopardize calorie intake in a smile child. I also believe that 2-3 year olds should be allowed to sooth themselves anyway they can. A six year old should be working toward eliminating the habit.<br /><br />4)Though we didn't need to do this, I think a person could easily re-apply on a child who is sleeping. It dries rapidly and is not thick like a typical nail polish. I did consider doing this with my six year old if she threw a fit during the re-appication process. Her third appication occurred with little protesting.<br /><br />In short, I have been exceptionally pleased with the results thus far. We will continue using this product for a while longer to ensure her success. Good luck to all the parents out there that are in our situation.   2586. The down 'n' dirty:<br />This stuff works as advertised, period!<br /><br />The Long Story:<br />I have a child who was a hardcore finger sucker until the age of five. My wife and I tried several &#34;home remedies&#34; such as bandages, soap, hot sauce, and caster oil. None of them seemed to be consistent or highly effect deterrents. We tried positive and negative reinforcement, but both proved fruitless. It seemed as though the habit was too strong to break, having been in practice for those five years since birth (our only child that preferred his digits over a pacifier).<br /><br />On the recommendation of a friend of my wife's, we decided to try Mavala Stop. Initially, we were skeptical, but decided it was worth a try. To our great surprise, the very first application effectively negated the problem for a good three weeks to a month. What was more amazing was, even while he slept, he didn't dare put his finger in his mouth! Impressive, to say the least. However, the after that time, I suppose the strength of the habit kicked in, and he was at it again. After another application, the problem was mitigated for a considerable while, only happening during sleep several weeks later. After one last use, the problem ceased to exist, even a year later.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />In my experience, this product has delivered on its promise. From interacting with other users, as well as reading reviews, I understand that the results will likely differ based on the child and the strength of the habit. Some people have had the fortunate &#34;one and done&#34; scenario, while others had to stay at it a bit longer. I would theorize that the sooner you use it, the better. The longer you wait, the harder it will be to break the habit (in my case, about four years overdue). I would highly recommend this product!
  2587. The point of this stuff is to taste horrible so you wont chew your nails. I have chewed mine for 27 years and for the first time in my life, I have nails. I was able to use this product for a few months and now have basically stopped chewing completely. I still do at times, but just re-apply some. The biggest complaint is if eating a sandwich of other &#34;finger&#34; type food, you end up tasting this when not even biting the nail.
  2588. Our 4yr old daughter stopped sucking her thumb in one day -- no joke. She was constantly sucking her thumb, when she was tired, bored, scared, hungry, and all through the night. We tried everything else like bandages, gloves, positive and negative reinforcement. But nothing was going to come between her and her thumb. One taste of the Mavala Stop on her thumb and she never wanted to put her thumb in her mouth again. A week later we've stopped using it and the habit is broken, no more sucking. I know this product won't work for every child, but it was the perfect solution for our child.

But after reapplying, I'm back to letting them start to look nice again.<br /><br />I've found what works best for me is to paint them a pretty color with a good quality nail polish (one that won't chip easily) and then continue to paint the Mavala on every morning during the week. I've found that if I can't see the whites of my nails growing longer, then the temptation to bite them is not as strong. This, coupled with the Mavala, is finally making my nails look normal. My cuticles also look healthier overall.   2679. I have unsuccessfully tried to get my youngest to stop sucking his thumb since he was just an infant. Because I had so much difficulty with his older brother (who didn't stop sucking until he was in elementary school and it already had moved his permanent teeth), I was determined to snip this one in the bud. However, nothing I tried worked (and I tried a LOT of thumb sucking remedies). I even got him to stop sucking one thumb, and instead he started sucking the other. However, due to the problems I had had with my older son, I thought it would be worth trying Mavala. I thought it would take a full month of using Mavala to get my three year old to give up his habit, but it took less than two weeks! It has been several months since, and he hasn't gone back to sucking his thumb. I love that it stays on for more than a day and doesn't require constant reapplication. I will say though, that the taste must be awful; the first night my son used it he ended up throwing up because he kept sticking his thumb in his mouth. It wasn't that the product itself made him throw up, but I think he just finally gagged from the taste.

  2774. I am 21 years old and have been a nail biter for as long as I can remember. This broke my habit. It took about 4 weeks for me, and I usually have to use it during finals week and things like that, so I don't go back to my old ways. The nice thing about this product is that the taste of it is so overwhelming, even if you consciously want to bite your nails, the effects of the product are not worth the satisfaction of biting. There are also a few expected downsides. One, the taste lingers for about 5 minutes after it touches your mouth, so if you are eating dinner, the food will taste awful. Secondly, this clear nail polish has a sheen to it, so being a 21 year old guy, I get a few people that look at me with a weird face asking, &#34;dude are you wearing nail polish?&#34; Aside from that I would discourage the use of this product with infants or kids young enough try cry when they taste something horrible, because this product is super potent. I personally find that to be a good thing. All in all, very effective product.

She was reluctant to put her fingers in her mouth because of the strong bitter taste. I've been using it for several months and the bottle still looks as full as it did the day it arrived.   2975. In just two weeks of using this product I have stopped biting my nails altogether. Sure, some urges from a habit are still there, but they're getting less and less noticeable. One bottle was more than enough to coat my nails through the whole process and was more than effective.<br /><br />There were a few downsides to applying polish to my nails, the most notable being the shine and smell of the product. After a hand wash or two, the shine actually faded while the repulsively bitter taste remained. The smell, too, also faded after one or two hand washes. I applied a coat to all of my nails once every two days for two weeks and still have most of the bottle remaining. The taste can only be described as bitter with no other notes... trust me, it will keep your fingers out of your mouth!<br /><br />The only real downside, and a perfectly fine one in return for finally kicking this awful habit, is that the bitter taste tends to find its way onto things other than your nails. I wiped my face one day only to realize I must have gotten some residue on my lips, only to lick them and taste the extremely bitter polish--all of this happened with completely dry nails. Same went with face washing and also eating hand-held foods; face washing seemed to run the polish a little, leading to bitter tastes on my skin and occasionally I would lick my finger while eating a taco or popcorn or something... I just had to be more careful and eventually it wasn't a problem.<br /><br />Let me put it this way. Looking down at my nails right now, any minor issues are completely excusable. I finally have normal looking, not gnarly nails, for the first time in my life.

  3033. I am currently 30 years old and I have bitten my nails for as long as I can remember. And I am not talking about a little nibble here and there, I am talking I would bite them until it was they were bleeding or it was to painful to continue, then I would move onto the next finger. When I was out of fingers I would then move into my cuticles. I had a real addiction problem to it and I have tried everything imaginable to try and stop the habit. I would never last more than a couple days without starting up the habit once again, I had gotten to the point where I had accepted it as a way of life. Out of nowhere one night I decided to look up new treatments for nail biters, thinking maybe some new miracle cure has came out. Really not knowing what I would find I searched nail bitting on Amazon and found this product and the reviews were amazing, I figured if anything had a chance it would be this product. I figured for the price if it didnt work I wouldnt be out much so I placed my order and it arrived a couple days later. First thing is first, this product is advertised as having a bad taste to curb your desire to bit your nails, so I painted it onto a finger, let it dry for a couple minutes and then took a lick, at first nothing at all, I thought the product was a failure. Then the taste hit me in the mouth like a run away freight train!! It is one of the worsts tastes I have ever came across, and it was not just a wow that was gross and then the taste went away, this disgusting taste lingered for a good 5 minutes or more! I did find it strange that the taste was delayed maybe 1-2 seconds or so but maybe it has to do with location of your bitter taste buds on your tongue? Regardless, I am not saying I am cured yet, but I went from a highly addicted nail biter to now I have not bitten my nails or cuticles in the past 2 weeks and I have almost zero urge to do so. Both my nails and cuticles are growing out and have actually required trimming and shaping. Something I have noticed is that I now catch lifting a finger to my mouth and think if I bite that nail I am going to taste that nasty stuff and I quickly put my hand back down haha!!<br /><br />I have been applying this product daily. I found that even after washing my hands several times a day and even taking a shower the taste still will linger for a second day though it is not as strong. I feel that if I did not apply it daily I would bite my nails on the second day and just deal wit the faint bitter taste.<br /><br />The only downside to this product, which I can not blame the product for but it must be noted.
